value.Name: Rangelands Of Namibia
value.LongDescription: Rangelands of Namibia: The goal of this project is to support a functioning system that connects Etosha National Park with Skeleton Coast Park to allow large mammals to migrate and local communities to live harmoniously as they once did. Our role is to increase the capacity of a local organization, Save the Rhino Trust (SRT), to help them protect the largest and expanding free-ranging population of black rhino in the world. By protecting the black rhino meta poplation in the Kunene region of NW namibia we will ensure that ecosystem services are functing for people and nature. There are 15 community wildlife conservancies in this 15-million-acre protected area that includes 2 national parks and 3 people's parks. SRT needs to change it's business model from straight protection with their own scouts to a skill transfer service organization building protection and monitoring capacity of the 15 communal conservancies in the region. This transformation requires some organizational restructuring, increased fundraising capacity and an incentive program for community game guards. This is the only way that communities will be able to monitor, protect and benefit from wildlife on these communal lands. SRT fills a critical vaccum here and so TNC's value add is to bring technical and financial support to SRT to ensure the national CBNRM program in Namibia is based on sound land use zoning and wildlife management. If lands are managed well, pastoralism is compatible with wildlife conservation. The widespread nature of pastoralism across eastern, southern and western Africa provides ample opportunity for replicating this approach beyond northern Namibia. Grasslands and arid lands are among the most highly threatened and least conserved habitat types in the world, and our work in Africa has great potential to ease those threats. We are already connecting our projects in Namibia and northern Kenya.

value.Name: WIO EBA
value.LongDescription: This project works at two scales - a site based scale and a regional policy scale. Primeiras and Segundas (site scale): Mozambique is one of the poorest countries in Africa: 90 percent of the population lives on less than US $2/day, life expectancy is 43 years, and 12.5 percent of the population is HIV/AIDS positive. In northern coastal Mozambique's Zambezi and Nampula provinces, the country's poorest, we are partnering with WWF, CARE and local fishing communities to help create a new 4.2â€“million-acre protected area in the Primeiras and Segundas (P&S) Archipelago that aims to protect biodiversity and improve the livelihoods of local people. The Conservancy's coral reef resiliency science and experience designing and implementing marine protected areas in the Pacific and Mexico complement the work of WWF and CARE to improve the viability and sustainability of a new marine protected area. West Indian Ocean EBA Partnership (regional scale): The Western Indian Ocean Partnership (WIOP) is an initiative that aims to promote national and regional commitments and actions at the highest levels to safeguard the resilience of the region's ecosystems so these can continue to provide benefits for sustainable livelihoods, address climate change impacts needs â€“ particularly adaptation-, and secure human security in the region. The Conservancy's role is to help build political and financial support by building a strong consortium of stakeholders. By working at both scales we hope to gain leverage and create enabling conditions for more resilient healthy human and natural communities.

value.Name: Water and Agriculture
value.LongDescription: Global FW Strategy. GFT contribution is focused on leverage: changing corporate water use to move toward enhanced sustainability, particularly in agriculture. Involves direct consultations with large multi-national companies to assess the water sustainability of their operations and supply chains, identifying water-related business risks for each company, and developing watershed restoration measures to reduce ecological impacts and business risk. The emphasis is on agricultural water use (e.g., supply chains), with an aim to improve agricultural water efficiency, reduce pollution to nearby lakes and rivers, and implement water-saving measures within local watersheds.

value.LongDescription: Protect critical river ecosystems and services globally through incorporating environmentally sustainable approaches into the practices of the world’s largest developers and governments in the regions with the greatest amount of potential and current hydropower development.The landscape of hydropower has evolved and countries such as China are now the major developers and funders of hydropower. To move the global hydropower sector toward sustainability—and to protect critical river ecosystems and services—the Conservany and other NGOs must build capacity and partnerships in the places where hydropower is being built and where decisions are being made. value.Name: LAR Lands
value.LongDescription: LACC Long-term Goal: Double food production with no new habitat lossThe Big Idea:Sustainable Intensification means boosting production on already cleared lands – spanning more than 100 million hectares in Latin America – while helping to protect natural habitat that might other- wise be cleared to produce food; “go” and “no-go” mapping will provide the scientific basis for intensification.What’s it going to take? The essential elements – information, technologies and practices, clear government regulation, and motivated companies, producers and consumers – exist or are in the works. A key gap is ac- cess to funding to help producers cover the upfront costs of transitioning to sustainable intensification tech- nologies and practices. The next step is to pull the disparate pieces together on specific landscapes and sea- scapes to demonstrate the business case for replication. What is the LACC’s opportunity? Within the LACC, we have a unique gathering of leading food-supply play- ers in industry, government and lending institutions. We propose to harness this asset to create collabora- tions to implement the LACC’s vision.

value.Name: FY15 TNC-wide Carbon Footprint
value.BriefDescription: Calculate a defensible, comprehensive, carbon footprint for all of TNC.
value.LongDescription: Carbon Footprint Analysis: We need a credible organization-wide carbon footprint analysis to track our success in lowering our carbon emissions. With this data, we can determine the organization’s baseline and identify challenges in our effort to achieve the stated outcome of reducing our carbon emissions by 20% by 2020. We will complete the next organization-wide carbon footprint analysis for TNC’s FY15 (FY15 will be used as the baseline value). We commit to completing this analysis annually from this point forward. To ensure transparency, we will post our footprint results on a TNC-owned public-facing website and include information on our sustainability efforts in our Annual Report.

value.BriefDescription: Bring the science of coral, oysters, marshes and mangroves to protect people and communities from storms and floods; saving millions in storm damage costs and keeping people safe from harm through collaborations with catastrophe modeling companies, Red Cross, World Bank, engineers and others.
value.LongDescription: Natural solutions can help us prevent and manage impacts to human and natural communities at great risk from natural hazards (e.g., droughts, storm surge, and floods), further exacerbated by climate change. The Nature Conservancy will focus its science, tools, and field projects initially on marine/coastal and freshwater vulnerability to harness strong experience/expertise and current opportunities. Places associated with this priority include the Gulf of Mexico, coastal New England in the United States, the desert Southwest of the United States, the island nations of the Grenadine Bank, the Solomon Islands, and other threatened coastal and freshwater systems in Latin America, Africa and Asia.

value.Name: Northern Kenya
value.BriefDescription: Accelerate growth of community-led conservation across 14 million acres, spreading peace and security for wildlife and people while increasing livelihoods, health care and education opportunities. Also, provide science to inform large-scale, regional infrastructure plans.
value.LongDescription: This project covers a vast unbroken landscape, roughly the size of California, in northern Kenya. It is a mosaic of conserved and connected private, communal and public lands that protect unique habitats, wildlife and fresh water across latitudinal and elevation gradients that help ensure resiliency to climate change while sustaining pastoral communities. The project area includes private land conservation, 19 community wildlife conservancies with more coming every year, a water fund, a critical partnership with Kenya Wildlife Service and national land and wildlife policy influence. Our vision for Northern Kenya is to increase the resiliency and improve the balance between pastoralists and wildlife by improving rangeland condition and strengthening local governance. Devolving resource management to the local level will help ensure ownership and proper management for current and future generations. By influencing policy for communal resource management we will get leverage across a much larger area within and beyond the borders of Kenya.nature.org link

value.Name: Africa Lands Strategy
value.BriefDescription: Help communities, governments and organizations conserve critical wildlife habitat and movement corridors, better plan and manage natural resource use and ensure that local communities who live alongside wildlife benefit from their conservation.
value.LongDescription: From the height of Mount Kilimanjaro to the plentiful coastline, Africa supports some of the most stunning places and wildlife left on Earth. Much remains as it was millennia ago, a fact to be rejoiced. But population growth and changes in climate have altered Africa's landscapes over the past 50 years. With increasingly complex challenges comes the need for evolved conservation strategies. The Nature Conservancy's vision for Africa is rooted in its people, who have not always been at the table when creating a plan for a sustainable future. Roughly 60% of Africa's lands and nearly 100% of Africa's waters are community property - shared resources that sustain iconic wildlife and some of the most vulnerable people on Earth. Conservation success in Africa will not happen without the involvement of local communities. It is these communal lands and waters outside of Africa's famed national parks that are critical to the continent's wildlife and people as the majority of the wildlife live or migrate outside of national park boundaries. Our projects in Kenya, Tanzania, Zambia, Gabon, Namibia and the West Indian Ocean focus on helping local communities, governments and organizations better manage important shared assets. Mostly this is about bringing benefit to local communities who live with wildlife but see no benefit. We realize that local communities need to own and get dividends from these critical resources. Conservation has to pay to be successful.

value.Name: Zambia
value.BriefDescription: Improve management on public and community lands within the 16-million-acre Kafue ecosystem; and, provide leaders with proven tools to avoid, reduce or mitigate development impacts and secure fresh water in the Kafue River Basin for people, nature and industry.
value.LongDescription: The Kafue Ecosystem in western Zambia is a 16.7 million acre complex of intact woodland and seasonally flooded grasslands that is dominated by the Kafue River and its tributaries. This system is dominated by Kafue National Park - a 5.5 million acre government managed protected area. Surrounding the Park are nine community managed areas called Game Management Areas (GMAs) that span an additional 11.2 million acres. This vast, unfenced system harbors two-thirds of Zambia's natural habitat types, including healthy examples of Miombo, Mopane and riparian woodland, deciduous teak forest, extensive floodplains, Papyrus swamp and flooded grasslands. These habitats support a magnificent range of wildlife including 158 mammal, 481 bird, 69 reptile, 36 amphibian and 58 fish species. This system includes much of the Kafue River catchment, the largest tributary to the Zambezi River and the drinking water source for the 2.5 million people living in Lusaka, the capital of Zambia. Additionally the Kafue River provides fish for people to eat, water for irrigation and floodplain farming.   Like so many places in the world, pressure on this system is increasing. The most direct threats to wildlife in the unfenced Kafue National Park (KNP) are unmanaged wildfire and rampant poaching. As a result, wildlife abundance in KNP has been degraded since the mid 1970s. Due to the relatively low wildlife numbers, tourism volumes have decreased reducing revenue for proper Park management. As a result, Park infrastructure needs rehabilitation and resource management is drastically insufficient.   The source of poaching and wildfire pressure comes from the communities living in the GMAs outside the park boundaries. These communities do not see sufficient benefit from protecting wildlife and their traditional lifestyle is marginalized by the Park. The Government has created mechanisms for trophy hunting fees to flow back to Community Resource Boards in each GMA but funds rarely flow due to lack of transparency and declining revenues being generated by safari hunting. We refer to this current unfortunate situation as ?aborted devolution? ? meaning that the intent of devolving resource management locally and sharing hunting revenue with communities was good, but it is not working effectively and communities, most hunting operators and the Zambian government are currently reviewing alternative devolved resource management strategy options.  The Nature Conservancy believes that local resource management when rewarded with a tangible stream of benefits is the most effective and sustainable conservation strategy. Our approach in the Kafue Ecosystem is to make community conservation successful by rebuilding the traditional authority, increasing strong local governance, diversifying and increasing revenue from improved resource management and job creation and by working in partnership with the Government. If communities see benefit and are encouraged to manage resources, pressure on wildlife will decrease and abundance will be restored over time.  The key strategy therefore, is to focus on creating a transparent and sustainable management system for the community lands around the park. This system will improve support to and acceptance of conservation activities on their lands by communities through the transparent and equitable distribution of revenues generated by community management of natural resources in community lands adjacent to the National Park by the people who are critical stewards of freshwater and terrestrial biological diversity and abundance. A successful model can be replicated and scaled across the Zambezi River Basin.

value.Name: Tuungane - Western Tanzania
value.BriefDescription: Safeguard fisheries, forests and chimpanzees while increasing access to reproductive health care, microfinance and agricultural support services for rural communities in the 4.8-million-acre Greater Mahale ecosystem on the Tanzanian shore of Lake Tanganyika.
value.LongDescription: The Greater Mahale Ecosystem has vast tracts of intact forest and woodland, the most easterly range and most viable population of the chimpanzee sub-species in Tanzania, and include the eastern side of Lake Tanganyika - the most intact great lake holding 17% of the worlds freshwater and high biological diveristy. This conservation area is a Eastern Afromontane Biodiversity Hotspot, the area boasts a great diversity of wildlife, including numerous rare and endemic species. However pressure on forest resources is increasing as populations grow, fisheries decline and road access increases. The goal of this project is to achieve both economic development and biodiversity conservation by empowering the local population to manage their natural resources responsibly. The Conservancy has completed CAPs in three regions of this project area and is now working with partners to implement climate change adaptation strategies to protect biodiversity and improve livelihoods by improving the systems resilience. Our initial work will focus on increasng protection in the forest lands east of Mahale National Park and devoping a coastal zone management plan on Lake Tanganyika in partnership with the Government, Pathfinder International and Frankfurt Zoological Society.

value.Name: African Great Lakes
value.BriefDescription: Work at basin and regional scales to increase coordination, strengthen capacity, inform policy and management with science, and support basin-scale ecosystem management in order to promote peace and security, public health and environmental sustainability in the African Great Lakes Region.

value.Name: Atlantic Coast Fisheries
value.BriefDescription: The goal of the Atlantic Coast fisheries strategy is to increase productivity of priority fish populations and the resiliency of habitat on which they depend by empowering fishing communities and putting science into action.
value.LongDescription: To restore ecologically important fisheries by improving the long-term viability of priority species and restoring habitat. By increasing access to good information, fisheries managers will be better able to make sustainable decisions and increase fish populations and fishing success.

value.Name: Longleaf Pine Forests
value.BriefDescription: Increase the footprint of longleaf pine forest to 8 million acres spanning 9 states to protect its ecological diversity while contributing resources to the globally important forest products industry.
value.LongDescription: Through additional land protection, restoration and management of public and private lands, increase the extent of longleaf pine to 8 million acres across its 9-state historic range to protect the unique ecological diversity associated with it while contributing to the globally important forest products industry anchored in the southeastern United States.

value.Name: Camp Meeting Rock (Goode 1)
value.BriefDescription: The GABU currently holds a CE on the Goode 1 tract. The BU will accept the donation of fee interest of this tract, which will enhance management opportunities, strengthen the projection of conservation resources and reduce financial and legal responsibilities associated with the CE.

value.Name: Camp Meeting Rock (Goode 2)
value.BriefDescription: The GABU currently holds a CE on the Goode 2 tract. The BU will accept the donation of fee interest of this tract, which will enhance management opportunities, strengthen the projection of conservation resources and reduce financial and legal responsibilities associated with the CE.

value.Name: Altamaha Ogeechee Estuarine Complex (Altama)
value.BriefDescription: Acquire 4100 acres of land on the Altamaha River to protect the freshwater, coastal and forest priorities in this geography.

value.Name: VT VYCC/Youth Conservation
value.BriefDescription: Tracks spending of Endowment and Reserves for Youth Conservation crews (primarily VT Youth Conservation Crew).

value.Name: VT Malletts Bay / Goad
value.BriefDescription: VT BU assist for land acquisition at Malletts Bay, part of Keurig-funded freshwater quality work.

value.Name: Decision Support System for Marcellus Shale Dev
value.BriefDescription: Decision Support System for Marcellus Shale Dev

PA URBAN & YOUTH INITIATIVES

value.Name: Maine Freshwater
value.BriefDescription: The restoration of the Penobscot River is an innovative effort to remove two dams and build a fish bypass around a third. On the Machias a 1,000 foot corridor on each side of the river and six tributaries is protected from development while public access is guaranteed forever.

value.Name: GA Altamaha River Acq Bradley-Cox 2
value.BriefDescription: Acquire fee title to enlarge existing wildlife management area and protect forests and freshwater river systems.

value.Name: GA Longleaf Pine
value.BriefDescription:
Engage public and private partners in longleaf pine restoration, management and protection through local implementation
and state coordination teams around designated significant geographic areas.

value.Name: GA Savannah River Project
value.BriefDescription:
1. Implement USACE dam operations and harbor mitigation activities on the Savannah River to sustain key natural features driven by river flow and water quality.  
2. Develop a water fund strategy to protect water quality along the Savannah River

value.Name: GA South Atlantic Seascape
value.BriefDescription: Sustain the economic and ecological values of the South Atlantic Whole System by siting new and expanding ocean and coastal activities in a manner that protects sensitive habitats and species, and balances ocean uses

value.Name: Georgia Atlanta Urban Project
value.BriefDescription: Georgia’s urban conservation project is currently developing a broad set of practical and effective strategies to address stormwater runoff pollution in metropolitan Atlanta.

value.Name: Delmarva Conservation Project
value.BriefDescription: This project is a collaboration that brings together conservation organizations, agribusiness, government agencies, & the scientific community to focus on achieving water quality and habitat goals that address significant resource concerns affecting the Chesapeake Bay and agricultural productivity.

value.Name: Chesapeake Bay
value.BriefDescription: TNC follows the science, leverages the policies, and brings partners and resources to bear for the Chesapeake Bay.  The work includes oyster-bed restoration, reduction in agricultural runoff, and lending expertise in relicensing dams for fish-passage, water-flow and sediment issues.
value.LongDescription: Chesapeake Bay Whole System FY2015

value.Name: Chesapeake Bay Agriculture Restoration
value.BriefDescription: Returning forested wetlands to this heavily ditched farmland improves habitat for diverse plants and animals. The habitat will improve water quality in Chesapeake Bay.  A monitoring program will help calculate water-quality benefits from the restored wetlands as they filter runoff from farms.

value.Name: Chesapeake Bay Oyster Restoration
value.BriefDescription: Oysters filter pollutants from the water while providing important nurseries to rockfish, crabs, and other marine life.  Harris Creek is the largest oyster restoration effort ever conducted in the Bay. Major activities include rebuilding more than 370 underwater acres with new reef substrate.

value.Name: Urban Water Solutions: Chesapeake Bay
value.BriefDescription: TNC’s Chesapeake Bay Program (incl MD/DC, PA and VA) proposes to address stormwater runoff (only growing source of pollution for Bay) through green infra projects in key urban areas. Projects will demonstrate the replicability and scalability of stormwater retention markets.

value.Name: MD Coastal Adaptation
value.BriefDescription: The MD/DC Chapter has identified climate resilience as a priority, and coastal adaptation as one strategy to support that priority. Coastal adaptation will include identifying natural solutions to promote resiliency in the face of coastal hazards such as storms and sea level rise.

value.Name: MA Oceans Permit Tuttle 2
value.BriefDescription: Fishing permit acquisition F/V Cuda 1061977, original permit #233175

value.Name: Gulf of Maine – Int Oceans Mgt
value.BriefDescription: Gulf of Maine – Int Oceans Mgt

value.Name: Boston Harbor Reef Building
value.BriefDescription: This project is focused on site selection and engineering work currently underway. The basic premise of the project is to build a reef in Boston Harbor using rock materials from the pending federal navigation channel dredge project.

value.Name: Gulf of Maine
value.BriefDescription: TNC works to reduce pollution and nitrogen levels in lakes, rivers and coastal bays, remove dams and bad culverts that inhibit fish migration, restore salt marshes, eelgrass beds,and oyster reefs. A major goal is to rebuild groundfish stocks.

value.Name: Gulf of Maine - Fisheries
value.BriefDescription: Accelerate the rebuilding of depleted groundfish populations, increasing ecological resilience and improving the fishing businesses through more sustainable fishing practices, better science and data to inform management and ensuring long-term access for traditional fishing communities.

value.Name: NH Clean Energy Future
value.BriefDescription: TNC has launched a “50‐State Climate Strategy”. NH will advance policy that reduces the impacts of energy development through the Mitigation Hierarchy; deploy science to inform and influence energy siting; and support replicable projects that demonstrate the use of clean energy technology.

value.Name: Northern Appalachians
value.BriefDescription: The Northern Appalachians is one of the most ecologically intact examples of its Forest Habitat type globally, abundant outstanding freshwater systems, highest diversity of carnivores in the east. ​​​​ Goals: retain large connected forest and maintain Terrestrial and aquatic habitat connectivity.

value.Name: Block Island Landscape
value.BriefDescription: Formed by glaciers, Block Island has beaches, sand dunes, coastal bluffs, and a variety of other ecosystems. It supports over 40 rare or endangered species. Thousands of migratory birds depend on the Island as a stopover along the Atlantic Flyway. Over 43% of the Island is now protected.

value.Name: Frank Carter Preserve
value.BriefDescription: The Pawcatuck River's Charlestown moraine and floodplain creates a variety of habitats on the 841 acre preserve, most notably the rare pitch pine/scrub oak barrens, vernal pools, and grasslands. TNC is restoring  habitat to help reverse the decline in grassland and shrub-nesting birds.

value.Name: Goosewing Preserve
value.BriefDescription: The Goosewing Beach Preserve is a magnificent system of pristine coastal pond, beach and dune environments purchased in 1989 by The Nature Conservancy and partners.  Conservancy staff have been actively managing breeding populations of rare piping plovers and state-threatened Least Terns.

value.Name: Sakonnet Landscape
value.BriefDescription: The Sakonnet's  forested hillsides, farms, marshes, and river habitats are habitat for songbirds and sea life. TNC's $5M  goal over the next five years is to protect an additional 750 acres of forest, field and shore, while building an army of volunteers to make our work even more sustainable.

value.Name: Tillinghast Pond Stewardship
value.BriefDescription: Tillinghast Pond Management Area has 2054 acres with miles of trails. TNC has a five-year trails plan with our partners and the National Park Service.  Opening 40 acres of early successional wildlife habitat  increases habitat diversity and benefits hawks, eastern bluebirds, and American woodcocks.

value.Name: RI Narrow River King Preserve
value.BriefDescription: This is a 161 acre on the Narrow River that we purchased this summer.  We are in the process of turning it into a flagship preserve in honor of David King of the Champlin Foundations.  This preserve will operate similar to Carter Preserve and TPMA

value.Name: RI PVD Metro
value.BriefDescription: This project is for our Providence Metro Program and track all activities and expenses.

value.Name: Queen's River (Harrop)
value.BriefDescription:
Accept donation via tax title transfer from the Town of West Greenwich to TNC for 6.4 acres in West Greenwich, RI.  Add parcel to the Queen's River Preserve and Management Area.

This project has been inactivated. This was opened in the HUB in error, it should be an Insight record only. Chris Bonner

value.Name: New York and New Jersey - CDRR
value.BriefDescription: New York and New Jersey - CDRR

value.Name: NY Species and Habitat Condition INACTIVE
Southern New England and Long Island
value.BriefDescription: Southern New England and Long Island

value.Name: Adirondacks Info Infrastructure
value.BriefDescription: A 6-month intern focused on planning and implementing the Chapter's pilot Flagship preserve in the Champlain Valley. Each intern has a broad exposure to all aspects of the Chapter's work -- fundraising, threat abatement, conservation science, stewardship, operations, communications and marketing.

value.Name: Mid-Atlantic Seascape
value.BriefDescription: TNC and partners are mapping and combining migration paths and shipping routes, wind patterns and wildlife habitat data, helping us see how the ocean is being used. New shipping routes or wind energy sites can be made while factoring in whale migration, critical habitats and fishing areas.

value.Name: WV-TNC-EDF Climate Partnership
value.BriefDescription: To align with the US Focal State Climate and Energy Policy project structure for focal states.

value.Name: WV TNC-EDF Climate Partnership - MacArthur
value.BriefDescription: To align with the US Focal State Climate and Energy Policy project structure for focal states.

value.Name: TNC-EDF Climate Partnership
value.BriefDescription: Project center for climate/energy initiative - mainly for those working at WO to use (not the states).

value.Name: XA TNC-EDF Climate Partnership - MacArthur
value.BriefDescription: Project center for climate/energy initiative - mainly for those working at WO to use (not the states).

value.Name: WV Cooperative Weed and Pest Management Area
value.BriefDescription: WV Cooperative Weed and Pest Management Area

value.Name: WV Larrivee Land Protection
value.BriefDescription: This is a project that will be used to begin our acquisition work with/for the Andrea Dyer Dalen Larrivee Irrevocable Trust.

value.Name: WV DOH Cranesville Swamp
value.BriefDescription: Department of Highways award to to trail work at Cranesville Swamp.

value.Name: Central Appalachians
value.BriefDescription: Conserve a network of large conservation areas that span multiple boundaries to protect forest and freshwater functions that provide natural habitats and contribute to healthy human communities.
value.LongDescription: Conserve a network of large, representative, and connected conservation areas, across political and administrative boundaries, capable of maintaining the important forest and freshwater functions that provide rich and resilient habitats and contribute to healthy human communities.

value.Name: Remote Soil Moiture Monitoring DELETE
value.BriefDescription: Prototype low cost remote soil moisture technology that can help farmers maximize their usage of water to reduce pressure on rivers with lower water flow.

value.Name: Canadian Boreal Forest
value.BriefDescription: Canada's Boreal Forest captures and stores 208 billion tons of carbon, is the nursery for 3 billion migrating birds, provides habitat for large wildlife, and is home to indigenous communities.  TNC provides expertise to help shape conservation plans for forests seriously threatened by development.
value.LongDescription: Improve the conservation and management of socio-ecological systems for the benefit of people and the maintenance of biodiversity.

value.Name: Water - To Be Assigned
value.BriefDescription: This is a behind-the-scenes project intended to group 'homeless' Insight records which are priorities and should be part of a challenge into a challenge classification for reporting purposes.

value.Name: Land - To Be Assigned
value.BriefDescription: This is a behind-the-scenes project intended to group 'homeless' Insight records which are priorities and should be part of a challenge into a challenge classification for reporting purposes.

value.BriefDescription: This is a behind-the-scenes project intended to group 'homeless' Insight records which are priorities and should be part of a challenge into a challenge classification for reporting purposes.

value.BriefDescription: This is a behind-the-scenes project intended to group 'homeless' Insight records which are priorities and should be part of a challenge into a challenge classification for reporting purposes.

value.Name: Global Information Services & Tools
value.BriefDescription: Develop a cascade of management information tools (scorecards, dashboards, reports, apps) to better inform decision makers in a timely manner. The project encompasses everything from Board and Executive Team tools, to individualized manager tools, and utilizes data sets from across the organization.

value.Name: Re-thinking Financial Planning & Mgmnt Process
value.BriefDescription: With new tools and data now available through the Major Systems Initiative, maximize the value of the financial planning and management process by taking a fresh look at the processes used by the organization to plan, manage, and report on financial information, including both funding and spending.

value.Name: MDDC Coastal Resil -Forests
value.BriefDescription: This is one of four main conservation bodies of work in the MDDC chapter and is where all work on Coastal Resilience - Forests will be charged.  note that Erika is the temp Finance lead so that we can get this project in and approved for budget upload by 2/25.

value.Name: MDDC Legacy Conservation Work
value.BriefDescription: This project is used for recording all expenses for Maryland and DC legacy projects.  The idea is to have the one project here rather than projects for individual places.

value.Name: India Freshwater Blueprint
value.BriefDescription: This is meant to align with the larger conservation framework.  This initial project includes the freshwater blueprint work and the subsequent identification of target cities for implementation.

value.Name: India Central Landscape
value.BriefDescription: This project is one of 3 initial conservation initiatives in India that is meant to align with the larger conservation framework. This initial project will be to define the Land and Agriculture strategy in India and could lead to the definition of new site-specific work.

value.Name: India Cities
value.BriefDescription: This project is one of 3 initial conservation initiatives in India that is meant to align with the larger conservation framework. This initial project will be to define the Cities strategy in India and could lead to the definition of new site-specific work.

value.Name: India Ganges
value.BriefDescription: Time and Expenses for the Ganges River project should be charged here.

value.Name: India e-flows
value.BriefDescription: This project will be sued to record time and expenses related to the e-flows work on the Ganges.

value.Name: US Public Lands Mitigation
value.BriefDescription: U.S. Mitigation Order: Conserve millions of acres by leveraging TNC’s energy field work, like the Mojave Desert, to ensure uptake of the U.S. Department of the Interior’s (DOI) secretarial order

value.Name: China Climate Policy Strategic Plan
value.BriefDescription: Expand support for including forests in emissions-trading systems in China and demonstrate other opportunities to protect, restore and better manage vital landscapes to sequester carbon. Pursue opportunities, such as expanded urban tree canopies, that offer climate mitigation and other benefits.

value.Name: Climate Policy: Adapt
value.BriefDescription: The policy component of our Climate Risk and Resilience Strategy will put in place the policies and funding to scale up investment in nature’s solutions for coastal resilience.

value.Name: Climate Policy: Finance
value.BriefDescription: Increase and leverage both public/private climate finance for nature’s mitigation and adaptation solutions. Including: steering the new Green Climate Fund’s resources to these areas, expanding opportunities for climate risk insurance products, and expanding the use of debt swap.

value.Name: Climate Policy: Implement
value.BriefDescription: We are designing an “NDC Implementation Initiative” to help countries implement the historic emissions reductions commitments that they made at the Paris climate summit in December 2015.   In the US we are already working with states to advance the Clean Power Plan.

value.Name: Climate Policy: Mitigate
value.BriefDescription: As the policy component of our Natural Carbon Solutions strategy, this project will work to increase political commitments and mobilize partners in support of significantly increasing the contribution of the land use sector to climate mitigation.

value.Name: U.S. Conservation Investment Campaign
value.BriefDescription: Raise hundreds of millions of dollars by shifting public conservation funding to an investment in nature’s solutions which includes LWCF full funding of $900 million/year, & boosts additional funding streams like Clean Water Act Revolving Loan Fund & effective mitigation funding
value.LongDescription: Nature solutions focus with a target for $3B in annual, long-term, & predictable conservation funding/policy outcomes that conserve lands and waters.

value.Name: National Advocacy Campaign
value.BriefDescription: SHOULD BE DELETED - See US Conservation Investment Campaign instead

value.Name: Conservation Information Hub
value.BriefDescription: The Conservation Information Hub, or "the Hub", will become TNC's conservation project database, providing the organization with a 360-degree view of conservation project information. It will fundamentally change and improve our ability to find and manage this data.

value.Name: Virtual by Design
value.BriefDescription:
Excelling As a Virtual Organization aka. Virtual by Design

VbD is an initiative part of ObD recognizing that the Conservancy operates primarily as a virtual organization and that GC/GS demands that we excel at being virtual.

https://connect.tnc.org/orgbydesign/virtual/SitePages/start.aspx

value.Name: Major Systems Care (MSC)
value.BriefDescription: A key strategy for sustaining our organizational effectiveness as defined in the Global Conservation Agenda and enabled by the Major Systems Initiative. It is a comprehensive effort to maintain and keep up-to-date the Conservancy’s core technology systems.

value.Name: tech4nature
value.BriefDescription: A catalyst fund to generate technological innovations that accelerate solutions to conservation challenges and bring the environmental movement into the digital age.

value.Name: Major Systems Initiative
value.BriefDescription: A comprehensive, Conservancy-wide eight-year effort (2011–2018) to upgrade and replace the Conservancy’s core technology systems for conservation, financial management, public and private fundraising, marketing, human resources, legal, and infrastructure.

value.Name: Global Coral Reefs
value.BriefDescription: Positively impact ~10,000 reef-dependent communities, ~5,000 reef managers and ~125,000 km2 of reef across the tropics – nearly half the world’s reefs – by protecting the most biodiverse & resilient reefs while also maintaining and restoring reefs that are economically important to communities.

value.Name: China Coastal Resilience
value.BriefDescription: Scope and establish a new marine program in China that includes making fisheries more sustainable and protecting key marine sites.

value.Name: Data poor science hub
value.BriefDescription: Low-cost stock assessments in unmanaged small scale fisheries: Quadruple the fisheries where we deploy data poor stock assessments and management targets and export our methods to three NGOs to put our key countries on a path to sustainable fishery management by 2017

value.Name: Peru Anchoveta
value.BriefDescription: Peru anchoveta reform: Reshape the world’s largest commercial fishery by working with artisanal fishermen to put 60 percent of the anchoveta artisanal fleet under regulation by 2017
BusinessUnits: N Andes and S. Central America (NASCA)

value.Name: Ocean Solutions - Strategy and Management
value.BriefDescription: $50 million Global Partnership for Oceans: Create this multi-donor trust fund and produce tangible results by the end of 2015 through supporting TNC habitat, fisheries and pollution abatement priorities

value.Name: Climate Risk & Resilence Science
value.BriefDescription: A Conservancy-led program that examines nature’s role in reducing coastal community risk which includes an approach and an online decision support tool for more detailed climate adaptation and resilience planning at national, regional and local levels.

value.Name: Coral Reef Capacity Building
value.BriefDescription: Support the work of The Reef Resilience Network which brings together managers from around the world to share ideas, experiences and expertise and strengthens abilities to effectively manage coral reefs threatened by warming seas, bleaching, pollution, and overfishing.

value.Name: Gulf Restoration
value.BriefDescription: Gulf of Mexico living shoreline restoration: Guide billions of dollars of post-BP spill restoration funding within the Gulf of Mexico  and build engineering sector partnerships over the next three years to restore hundreds of miles of oyster reef and other living shoreline by 2024

value.Name: Ocean Protection & Planning
value.BriefDescription: Effectively manage large coastal and ocean areas
value.LongDescription: Effectively manage large coastal and ocean areas

value.Name: Mapping Ocean Wealth
value.BriefDescription: Develop the science and tools to describe ocean ecosystem benefits in spatial terms, and develop multiple pathways for the uptake and application of this fundamentally new kind of knowledge about the oceans to improve investments in conservation and economic development.

value.Name: Ocean Use Planning
value.BriefDescription: Ensure that conservation is a key element of ocean planning, and that stakeholders are engaged in the process, so that effective marine spatial plans are created and implemented successfully. Use spatial data, science and other information to inform zoning, management and implementation needs.

value.Name: CRR Flooding Engineering Partnership
value.BriefDescription: Flood risk engineering partnership: Launch a partnership with engineering firms to incorporate the value of natural systems in engineering models and projects to help reduce flooding risk while also protecting and restoring nature

value.Name: Global Tuna Action Plan
value.BriefDescription: Catalyze dramatic on-the-water improvements that reduce bycatch of at-risk species like sharks, turtles and rays, improve fleet accountability and align tuna harvest levels with scientific guidance in the Western and Central Pacific Ocean and potentially the Indian Ocean.

value.Name: CRR Re-Insurance Partnership
value.BriefDescription: Re-insurance industry flood risk reduction: Launch a model program with at least one major re-insurer (likely Swiss Re) to help reshape the industry to fostering investment in natural solutions to reduce risk and reduce insurance costs

value.Name: Coastal Wetlands For The Future
value.BriefDescription: Deliver a net increase in the extent of wetlands worldwide by mainstreaming coastal wetland protection into coastal planning and financial markets.

value.Name: Oceans
value.BriefDescription: Spark a revolution in ocean conservation by influencing maritime and development sectors in a way that supports smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in marine and coastal environments.

value.Name: Alliance Against Illegal Fishing
value.BriefDescription: TNC is launching a global effort to tackle the problem of illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing (IUU) that aims to eliminate fish products of illegal origin from major import markets, close access to ports by vessels that fish illegally and build public awareness and demand for legal fish.

value.Name: Global Oceans Governance
value.BriefDescription: The Conservancy is exploring how public and private interests can work together to create new or strengthened ocean governance models that can be applied at all levels.

value.Name: Sustainable Fisheries
value.BriefDescription: The Nature Conservancy is partnering with fishermen, industry and local communities to design, test, and implement innovative management approaches and new business models that result in viable local fisheries, stable supplies of seafood and marine conservation.
value.LongDescription: The Nature Conservancy is partnering with fishermen, industry and local communities to design, test, and implement innovative management approaches and new business models that result in viable local fisheries, stable supplies of seafood and marine conservation. Key tactics we are deploying include: working with fishing associations to ensure access rights to fishing grounds, providing incentives for the use of selective and benign fishing gear, developing low-cost assessment methods for data-poor fisheries, and modernizing the use of fisheries data and information by fishermen. Places associated with this priority include the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts of the United States, the Humboldt Current of Peru and Chile, Indonesia and the Gulf of California. This Global Priority relates directly to the Global Challenge of Restoring Our Oceans and Coasts.

value.Name: Global Aquaculture
value.BriefDescription: Grow the aquaculture industry in a sustainable manner, using practices that benefit the environment and provide stable sources of income by focusing on sectors that can deliver several services, or are poised to make innovative industry-changing leaps.

value.Name: China Breathable Communities Projects
value.BriefDescription: Each year, 500K people in China die prematurely from polluted air. We will build off the info rom the global air quality study to identify key cities and neighborhoods in China where nature (increased trees and other vegetation) might play a role in cleaning and cooling air to improve public health.

value.Name: Cities
value.BriefDescription: The Global Cities program is demonstrating the power of nature to help cities be more resilient, livable and flourishing through initiatives around urban water management, air and heat, biodiversity and community and youth engagement.

value.Name: Nature Prescription
value.BriefDescription: The Conservancy will embark on a creative multi-year campaign to communicate nature’s power and value to millions of city residents to change attitudes and modify the behavior of people in cities to embrace nature and understand the role it plays in making their lives better.

value.Name: Breathable Communities Demonstration Projects
value.BriefDescription: On-the-ground projects in at least two cities to demonstrate the power of green infrastructure to improve air quality and reduce the impact of urban heat islands.

value.Name: Planting Healthier Air
value.BriefDescription: A global urban air quality study, similar to Urban Water Blueprint, to test the hypothesis that nature can play a significant role in helping clean and cool city air. This study will give cities, int’l agencies and public health officials data about the value of incorporating nature into their work.

value.Name: Breathable Communities
value.BriefDescription: Air quality and urban heat islands result in thousands of deaths annually. TNC is promoting the use of green infrastructure to improve air quality and reduce the impact of heat islands while accelerating and expanding the billions of public and private dollars invested in these natural solutions.

value.Name: Cities by Design
value.BriefDescription: The goal of the Cities biodiversity strategy is to significantly decrease biodiversity loss in and around cities due to urban expansion over the next decade by helping create a new generation of connected, biodiverse protected areas in some of the world’s fastest growing metropolitan regions.

value.Name: Indoor Health Study
value.BriefDescription: An experiment to test how a large scale office greening affects worker productivity, mental well-being, and increases their connection with nature. Result would be a white paper combining results with a financial analysis to show costs and benefits of large-scale indoor greening project.

value.Name: Green Infrastructure Tool
value.BriefDescription: The Natural Infrastructure Screening Tool will quantify the potential for natural infrastructure for cities around the world. It will provide municipal planners with a detailed tool that is sophisticated enough for on-the-ground planning of natural infrastructure.

value.Name: Cities by Design Demonstration Projects
value.BriefDescription: Demonstration projects in at least two cities to minimize biodiversity loss in and around cities by helping create a new generation of connected, biodiverse protected areas in some of the world’s fastest growing metropolitan regions.

value.Name: LAR Stormwater Demonstration Projects
value.BriefDescription: TNC will demonstrate the power of natural infrastructure for addressing stormwater challenges and improving health and quality of life in at least two cities in Latin America.

value.Name: Greater Melbourne
value.BriefDescription: Melbourne, Australia’s 2nd-largest city, is known for its greenspace, yet has no strategy for managing biodiversity. Working in conjunction with the 100RC Program, and with the city's resilience strategy, TNC will develop a Melbourne Biodiversity Conservation Strategy (Urban Forest Plan).

value.Name: LA River Project
value.BriefDescription: LA’s Urban work is focused on integrating natural solutions into transformative urban infrastructure programs that offer both ecological and human benefit. This includes projects to enhance the Los Angeles River, address stormwater, and develop a regional biodiversity vision for people and nature.

value.Name: Biodiversity Study (Global Cities)
value.BriefDescription: The Conservancy is partnering with faculty at the Yale School of Forestry on a study to analyze where urban growth will have the highest impacts on biodiversity in the coming decades, and where increased or improved governance can help mitigate those impacts.

value.Name: Habitat Network
value.BriefDescription: The goal of the Habitat Network is to bring people together to meaningfully restore ecological function. If we can help suburban and urban residents view their backyards in a new light, we are building a constituency to help us reframe the connection between nature and cities.

value.Name: People and Nature
value.BriefDescription: Engage people in cities to care about nature through volunteer opportunities, engagement with youth and underserved communities, and through innovative programs to bring nature into schools, workplaces and hospitals to demonstrate the power of nature for health, learning, productivity and well-being

value.Name: Urban Water Solutions
value.BriefDescription: Stormwater is one of the greatest environmental challenges faced by cities. It also contributes to poor health and quality of life for people.  TNC aims to improve water quality and human quality of life by increasing the use of natural infrastructure in cities to address stormwater problems.

value.Name: AP Stormwater Demonstration Projects
value.BriefDescription: TNC will demonstrate the power of natural infrastructure for addressing stormwater challenges and improving health and quality of life in one to two cities in Asia Pacific.

value.Name: Urban Water Solutions: Puget Sound  (Seattle, WA)
value.BriefDescription: TNC WA is accelerating solutions to Puget Sound’s #1 pollution problem—stormwater. Using nature-based solutions to urban runoff, we solve a water quality problem & make communities vibrant, livable, equitable & competitive. Our cross-sector coalition is working to bring nature back into our cities.

value.Name: Emerging Urban Water Initiatives – North America
value.BriefDescription: Create a Stormwater Community of Practice to share knowledge & deploy internal expertise. Test and demonstrate the power of nature as an urban water solution in key cities, including Bridgeport, CT, Chicago, IL, Hanava, Cuba, Atlanta, Birmingham, Phoenix, Portland, OR and more.

value.Name: Kansas Central Great Plains Grasslands Initiative
value.BriefDescription: Kansas Central Great Plains Grasslands Initiative

value.Name: Beals Healthy Streams Initiative
value.BriefDescription: David T. Beals III Healthy Streams for Kansas Initiative

value.Name: Grand River Grasslands
value.BriefDescription: The Conservancy is preserving prairie chicken habitat of more than 80,000 acres total of protected prairie and grasslands. Other breeding birds requiring these open grasslands include short-eared owls, northern harriers, upland sandpipers, Henslow’s sparrows and sedge wrens.

value.Name: Iowa Boone River
value.BriefDescription: The Boone River flows nearly 100 miles and joins the Des Moines River. TNC works with partners to establish science-based conservation goals such as water chemistry, habitat improvements and hydrology. The goal is to conserve native freshwater biodiversity and to benefit the agricultural community.

value.Name: Boone River
value.BriefDescription: The Boone River flows nearly 100 miles and joins the Des Moines River. TNC works with partners to establish science-based conservation goals such as water chemistry, habitat improvements and hydrology. The goal is to conserve native freshwater biodiversity and to benefit the agricultural community.

value.Name: Broken Kettle Grasslands
value.BriefDescription: The 3000 acre Broken Kettle Grasslands contains prairie ridgetops with variety of plants and animals and  many species of prairie butterflies. It hosts the largest tract of contiguous native prairie left in Iowa.  Fire and bison grazing are at the core of TNC's management efforts.

value.Name: Cedar Hills Sand Prairie
value.BriefDescription: The 90 acre preserve sits atop a broad sand ridge between the Cedar River and Beaver Creek.  It contains a dry sand prairie on upland ridges, a large sedge meadow and small fen in a swale, and small marshes in depressions. The site is a resource for teaching and research in Northern Iowa.

value.Name: Iowa Little Sioux
value.BriefDescription: Little Sioux River flows through glacial deposits to the Missouri River. Once tallgrass prairie, there are now remnants, pothole wetlands, calcareous fens, and oak woodlands.  Threats  include lack of fire, inappropriate tree planting and over-grazing. TNC helps protect 2,700 acres in the Valley.

value.Name: Kentucky Big Rivers Corridor
value.BriefDescription: Kentucky Big Rivers Corridor is a partner project with KY Dept of Fish and Wildlife Res and KY Div of Forestry protecting 6856 acres in Union & Crittenden counties, KY at the confluence of the Tradewater and Ohio rivers. Current work on this project is being funded thru a NAWCA grant.

value.Name: Kentucky Louisville Urban Conserv

value.Name: Kentucky Green Heart Project
value.BriefDescription: The Louisville Green Heart Project seeks to test the hypothesis that exposure to neighborhood greenspace diminishes cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk by decreasing the levels of air pollution. This study will provide much-needed quantitative data on how urban greenspaces impact health.
value.LongDescription:
The Louisville Green Heart Project
Full Project Description

Problem:  Data show that Louisville neighborhoods adversely impacted by a sparse tree canopy, higher temperatures (urban heat island hot spots), and a variety of environmental justice issues, are also neighborhoods where residents have poor health outcomes. Previous research has demonstrated that air pollution increases rates and severity of heart disease, obesity and diabetes and that the neighborhoods with poor air quality coincide with areas of elevated health risks.  Louisville routinely leads the region in poor air quality and has high rates of asthma and cardiovascular disease (CVD).   These health problems place a large burden on city residents, especially those that are economically disadvantaged, and cost hundreds of millions of dollars ($650 million annually for CVD alone). 

Opportunities:  Pioneering work at the University of Louisville suggests that residential proximity to major roadways and exposure to particulate air pollution are associated with chronic cardiovascular injury.  Additional work in this field has suggested that areas with high levels of greenness (trees, shrubs, and other dense vegetation) are likely to experience improved cardiovascular health, better health outcomes, and reduced hospital admissions. It thus appears possible that increasing the greenness of an area through targeted tree and vegetated buffer plantings may lead to reductions in ambient air pollution and other environmental factors that contribute to poor health. 

Taken together, the scientific evidence suggests that increasing trees, vegetation, and overall green space within cities will improve citizen health. Pulmonary, metabolic and cardiovascular disease are among the leading causes of death in Louisville and therefore a decrease in the incidence, prevalence and severity of these diseases achieved through a decrease in air pollution is likely to yield significant health cost savings.  Importantly, this view also illuminates potential new opportunities to account for health cost savings as a possible mechanisms to fund large scale greening required to address Louisville’s and other cities increasing urban heat island effects, poor air quality, and other environmental challenges. We believe that robust quantification of avoided healthcare costs resulting from such health improvements could pave the way to ultimately establish a viable and scalable funding stream to implement neighborhood greening programs.
   

Our vision: Despite the demonstrated link between air quality and health impacts, and the link between a lack of trees, vegetation and decreases in air quality, there is surprisingly little quantitative data demonstrated that more vegetation leads directly to better health outcomes.   The Louisville Green Heart project seeks to test whether such a direct link is there and can be effectively measured and quantified.  In other words, we will use science to demonstrate whether we can improve health outcomes through the implementation of a neighborhood-scale greening plan.  More broadly speaking, we seek to reduce health inequities in Louisville and demonstrate the role nature can play to significantly improve human health and other measures of community wellness.   Ultimately, this project seeks to test the benefits nature can deliver to address Louisville’s current environmental realities and their immediate health impact by improving the city’s long-term resiliency.  More specifically, the Green Heart project seeks to answer the following key questions:

•	Can nature filter and reduce the availability of damaging fine particulate matter (PM2.5) from neighborhoods effectively to improve CVD outcomes?
•	Which suite of vegetation, species, densities and proximities are best for the job?
•	How does the presence/absence of nature affect novel biomarkers of subclinical cardiovascular injury such as circulating stem cells, plasma thrombotic response, and inflammation to evaluate the mechanisms underlying CVD risk?  
•	What does greening a neighborhood effectively cost? Can we reduce the healthcare cost (e.g., the rates of hospital admissions and the length of stay) for CVD by using nature-based planning tools, thus, demonstrating a return on investment (ROI)? 
•	Can we determine how increasing greenspace affects other critical measures of neighborhood health (crime, educational performance, etc)?
•	Could this project result in private sector healthcare policy outcomes that place emphasis on investing in nature as preventative medicine, thus injecting additional capital for nature?

Output: A neighborhood scaled greening project, a rigorous study and report that could be disseminated in print or electronic form. The Conservancy anticipates the report will have the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) as a key collaborating institution.  The report would focus on air pollution and CVD, but has the potential for sub-studies around social measures, real-time asthma monitoring, or other co-benefits from nature. 

Audience:  International agencies (e.g., WHO), national agencies (e.g., EPA, NIEHS, USFS), healthcare industry, urban planners, city officials, philanthropists, and community leaders.  Ultimately, we aim to spur the development of new public health policies that incentivize the use of nature to achieve better health outcomes and the formation of model approaches that could be readily transported to other cities in both developing and developed countries.  
 
Challenges:  While it is currently unclear to what extent geographic, urban and ecologic features of Louisville are related to poor health outcomes, it is clear that solutions to our local problems will have to come from both public and private interests and are likely to extend across all land use types: residential, commercial, industrial and institutional. Therefore it is essential to fully engage each of these sectors to help inform and drive the development of our proposed community engagement efforts. Extensive community engagement is vital to development of the greening plan and implementation of that plan in the selected neighborhoods.   We are already reaching out to faith-based communities, neighborhood groups, and organizations that specialize in meaningful and successful engagement with diverse constituencies, and we will work with all these entities as the project continues to move forward. 

What is transformational:  Successful completion of this project will lead to a rigorous evaluation of the link between urban vegetation and greenspace with cardiovascular disease and generate new knowledge relevant to the identification of the environmental determinants of health. Establishing a robust econometric model for the health cost savings directly attributable to urban ecology would open new funding channels for our troubled urban ecosystems.  From the extensive data generated by the study, we will be able to delineate the contribution of the underlying psychological, behavioral, and biochemical mechanisms to the relationship between CVD and neighborhood greenness. The results of this project will also provide us a new understanding of how urban greenspaces affect neighborhood livability, community cohesion, economic activity and geographic resilience.

Partners:  
Meera Bhat – Dir., The Nature Conservancy NA Cities Program, study design
Pascal Mittermaier – Dir., The Nature Conservancy Global Cities Program, fundraising
Bill Toomey – Dir., The Nature Conservancy Healthy Trees, Healthy Cities Program, community outreach
Chris Chandler – Dir., The Nature Conservancy Cites Program Kentucky Chapter, project manager
Dr. Ted Smith – Dir., Institute for Healthy Air Water and Soil, Louisville Chief of Innovation, study design
Dr. Aruni Bhatnagar – Dir., Diabetes and Obesity Center, University of Louisville, clinical study design
Brent Bucknam – Principal Hyphae Labs & Urban Biofilter, Oakland, California, vegetation design
Maria Koetter –Dir. of Sustainability, City of Louisville, study design 
Mrs. Christina Lee Brown – Philanthropist, study design
Dr. Jay Turner – Associate Professor & Director of Undergraduate Programs, air quality specialist
Funding: 
To address the health and greening problem quickly, we will need more resources than local government and a single foundation funding source can provide. Additional funding for Health research is being sought through National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS), and implementation funding through The Nature Conservancy, Humana, Passport Healthcare, Owsley Brown Family Foundation, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and The Helmsley Charitable Trust. 

Preliminary Timeline:
1.	Identify study target neighborhoods (currently ongoing)
2.	Develop greening plan: (currently ongoing with draft by 01/28/16 - 08/15/16)
3.	Collect initial health and environmental data (12/01/2015 - 08/30/16 2016) 
4.	Implement initial greening pilot areas (Spring/Fall 2016)
5.	Develop and perform cross-sectional studies (currently ongoing)
6.	Develop and submit a NIEHS health and greenness grant (April 2016)
7.	Gather follow-up subject and greenness data (3yrs - 5yrs)
8.	Longitudinal analysis (3yrs - 5yrs+)

value.Name: Michigan Saginaw Bay
value.LongDescription:
Saginaw Bay is an ecologically significant and highly productive embayment of Lake Huron, supporting a diversity of fish, waterfowl, and other wildlife; Saginaw Bay has the “largest concentration of coastal wetlands in the Lake Huron Basin” and serves as Lake Huron’s most important source for several fish species, including walleye (Liskauskas et al. 2007). The Saginaw Bay watershed is the largest in the state of Michigan, spanning 5.5 million acres and covering parts of 22 counties. The ecological health of Saginaw Bay and its tributaries is critically important to not only Lake Huron, but the entire Great Lakes ecosystem, as this watershed provides vital ecosystem services for both nature and people, including fish spawning habitat and abundant farmland.

Saginaw Bay was designated as a Great Lakes Area of Concern (AOC) in 1995, threatened by high sediment and phosphorus contributions from tributaries, contaminated sediment and loss of wetlands (Public Sector Consultants, Inc. 2002). At the time of its designation, Saginaw River and Bay had 12 of a possible 14 beneficial use impairments (BUIs).

Although there is widespread awareness about the role sediments and nutrients play in diminishing the health of Saginaw Bay, these problems persist. One significant source of excessive sediment and nutrient loading is through agricultural activity, which has well-documented impacts on aquatic systems (Blann et al. 2009) and is widespread in the Saginaw Bay watershed. Collectively, the 22 counties that are wholly or partially encompassed by the Saginaw Bay Watershed account for 45% of Michigan’s agricultural land (MUCC 1993).

In the fall 2012, as part of The Nature Conservancy in Michigan’s strategic planning process, the Saginaw Bay watershed was identified as one of 13 geographic conservation priority areas throughout the state. The Conservancy has had a long-standing presence in this region, especially in the Shiawassee River watershed, where on-the-ground staff has worked to target agricultural Best Management Practices (BMPs) to improve aquatic habitat and restore wetlands in the Shiawassee Flats area. While TNC is not doing active restoration in the Saginaw Bay watershed at this time, it is employing traditional conservation strategies and testing new tools to achieve targeted, outcome-based conservation that will benefit people and nature. The work being done in Saginaw Bay is also included as part of the Agriculture and Altered Hydrology strategy of the Great Lakes Project and is one of the three most significant bay areas in the Great Lakes basin (the other two are Green Bay and Maumee Bay).

value.Name: Great Lakes Agriculture
value.BriefDescription: The Great Lakes region supports a large and diverse agricultural economy whose viability is dependent upon water for irrigation and processing. Altered water flows across and through agricultural lands threatens the health of aquatic ecosystems and the availability of clean water people depend upon.

value.Name: Great Lakes Information Mgmt & Delivery System
value.BriefDescription: Advancing shared goals and collaborative solutions to complex conservation problems facing the Great Lakes region

value.Name: Great Lakes Connectivity
value.BriefDescription: Dams, road-stream crossings and culverts have altered how water flows through watersheds leading to degraded habitat for aquatic wildlife and poorer water quality.  The Conservancy is identifying ways to re-establish healthy connections between rivers and lakes to improve the health of watersheds.

value.Name: Great Lakes Fisheries
value.BriefDescription: The aquatic food web, a complex system of freshwater life forms, significantly affects the economy, recreation, fisheries, and overall health of the Great Lakes.  TNC is working with partners to ensure that native food webs are ecologically functional and capable of supporting sustainable fisheries.

value.Name: Great Lakes Coastal
value.BriefDescription: The nearshore waters, shoreline and coastal uplands are the region's most ecologically diverse and productive systems - and among the most heavily used by people.  The Conservancy is working to restore coastal wetlands, prioritize work in coastal systems, and develop sustained funding.

value.Name: Great Lakes Forests
value.BriefDescription: Northern forests help moderate regional climate, remove carbon from the atmosphere, filter the headwaters of the Great Lakes and provide critical habitat for a wide range of species.  The Conservancy aims to improve forest management to support economic uses while helping wildlife habitat.

value.Name: Grassland Conservation Program
value.LongDescription: The Grassland Conservation Business Plan (CBP) is intended as an implementation blueprint for the Conservancy’s grassland work in Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota through 2020, in keeping with the framework, strategies and goals of the Chapter’s 2007-2017 strategic plan. The focus of the CBP is on strategic plan themes of land protection and management to address pervasive threats to the habitat, leveraging public funding and our agency partners’ conservation efforts and adapting to climate change. The CBP will serve as a guide to our conservation investments over the next five years and will inform our role in the new global campaign and the next iteration of the Chapter strategic plan.The grassland conservation program will deploy three primary strategies—protection, ecological management, and collaboration—to improve and sustain functioning grassland systems across our grassland portfolio sites. The program focus is on 12 priority landscapes totaling 2.4 million acres, with outcomes of maintaining grassland cover and continuity, improving condition of grasslands, and sustaining a ranching culture in our priority landscapes. Grasslands of the Great Plains are threatened by a number of forces, such as conversion to row-crop agriculture, ecologically inappropriate disturbance practices, invasive species and climate change. Applying broad-scale and complementary strategies to protect the extent and improve the condition of native grasslands on private lands is the key to protecting and sustaining our remaining prairie ecosystems.Our theory of change is that through strategic use of our existing land and staff assets, building new capacity for protection and management on private lands and exploring new models for sustaining the economics of private ranching, we will leverage conservation at scale on private lands in our priority grassland landscapes. To accomplish this change, we will:PROTECT the integrity of native grassland ecosystems through targeted and accelerated use of easements and fee acquisition of land.TRANSFORM the scale and impact of our partners’ work through collaborative planning and by leveraging public funding.INSPIRE landowners to adopt new grassland management practices using our preserves as demonstration platforms.Protection: A central theme of our program is the permanent protection of grasslands, one of the most threatened habitats in the world with the objective of protecting an additional 46,400 acres within our priority landscapes across all three states (Mgmt A). Our primary protection tools include selective fee-title acquisition by the Conservancy and assisting our partners in acquiring conservation easements on private lands. We will expand the use of Conservancy employed Conservation Easement Technicians embedded in partner offices to accelerate the implementation of federally funded easement programs. Success depends on securing sufficient public and private funding through strategic collaborations (Finance A) and innovative market-based approaches. Over the next five years we will begin implementing a carbon credit easement program in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to create a revolving fund of conservation dollars that leverage and accelerate existing easement programs. The amount of grass cover is largely influenced by policy work in conjunction with our partners, such as Farm Bill and federal and state easement programs. Our goal is to reduce the loss of grasslands within our priority landscapes (Policy A).4Ecological Management: Condition matters. In addition to “keeping the green side up,” we strive to improve the ecological health of grasslands. With a focus on Nature Conservancy and private ranching lands, we will accelerate the use of critical management tools like prescribed fire (Mgmt B) and conservation grazing to “move the conservation needle.” We also envision a central role for our preserves and partners’ lands in helping define “sustainable grazing,” potentially as a component of a larger sustainable beef strategy. We will gage our success by the degree to which native-dominated plant communities increase on actively managed Conservancy preserves, striving for 5% (Eco A). We will leverage our preserves as demonstrations to facilitate ecologically beneficial management techniques on private lands. This outcome will be achieved through direct action on neighboring private lands and by convening workshops and other learning opportunities for landowners within our priority geographies (People B).Collaboration: The ambitious targets for protection and ecological management laid out above will only be possible through strong collaboration with agency partners and private ranchers/ranching associations. We will expand the Conservancy’s capacity to participate and lead on collaborative processes that leverage our traditional work by influencing partners, providing resources, and capitalizing on TNC subject matter expertise. Further, we will work directly with private landowners within priority geographies to enhance conservation outcomes on private lands and help maintain a ranching culture (People A). We will also strengthen our collaboration within the Conservancy and with private producers through participation in the Grasslands Conservation Network.Finance and Capacity: The Grassland program constitutes approximately 70% of the Chapter’s overall budget, or ~$7.5 million, consistent with the distribution of grasslands across our three states, and including the majority of the Conservancy’s preserve acreage and nearly 40 FTEs in FY2015. To achieve the conservation outcomes called for in the plan requires moderate to aggressive growth of the Program to a total budget of about $18.5 million by FY2018, primarily through increased field capacity for work on private lands and funds for additional protection. The plan assumes that current levels of baseline funding and staffing will remain in place, while increasing our impact at the landscape scale requires new resources and new investment, most significantly in increased seasonal field crews, new easement technicians and grazing infrastructure for key preserves. Most of this new investment (75-80%) is projected to come from public funding sources, market-based strategies, and by leveraging existing partner programs to the landscapes we care most about. To leverage an estimated $30-50 million in public funds for protection we expect to need $3-3.5 million in private revenue.

value.Name: Papua New Guinea
value.BriefDescription: Papua New Guinea's indigenous clans, who control 97% of the nation's lands and coastal areas, are the front line and primary benefactors of effective conservation.
value.LongDescription: Papua New Guinea's indigenous clans, who control 97% of the nation's lands and coastal areas, are the front line and primary benefactors of effective conservation. We worked with them the government and civil society to develop conservation and sustainable use legislation that supports their rights and long-term interests. Today, we focus on linking their local action with global compensation systems like REDD+, PES and Fairtrade. These efforts contribute directly to Papua New Guinea's international commitments and economic development and policy priorities, including the Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs, Fisheries and Food Security and aligned to PNG Government's Vision 2050 climate change and environmental sustainability goals.

value.Name: Water
value.BriefDescription: Change fundamentally the way land managers, water utilities, hydropower operators, cities and corporations use and manage our most precious resource—water-for the benefit of both people and nature.

value.Name: Securing Water
value.LongDescription: The Global Securing Water Program will target a selected number of water basins to demonstrate tools, approaches, and policies to reduce the supply/demand gap between clean, accessible, reliable water supply and demand in basins in a sustainable manner that provides water to people and nature. Securing sufficient, clean and reliable water sources to meet human needs without irreversibly degrading aquatic systems such as lakes, aquifers and rivers will require fundamental changes in how we manage freshwater. Water security starts with securing the watershed, by conserving and investing in its network of natural infrastructure that supplies water—aquifer recharge areas, rivers, lakes and their riparian zones—but, to be successful it must also include reducing and re-balancing water use and consumption among key sectors (agriculture, cities, and industrial uses).

value.Name: Saving Great Rivers
value.BriefDescription: The mission of the Great Rivers Partnership is to bring together diverse partners and best science to expand options for achieving the sustainable management and development of the world's Great Rivers and their basins.
value.LongDescription: The mission of the Great Rivers Partnership is to bring together diverse partners and best science to expand options for achieving the sustainable management and development of the world's Great Rivers and their basins. We seek shared solutions to common land- and water-use dilemmas, recognizing the inescapable linkages that connect our economy, human well-being and ecosystem sustainability. We view our history and leadership role in the Mississippi River Basin as an important regional asset, and a foundation for promoting the global exchange of knowledge and expertise.

Accomplishments.AccomplishmentText: The Conservancy wrote a report, “The New Frontier of Hydropower Sustainability: Planning at the System Scale,” for the Inter-American Development Bank. The report identifies key drivers and limitations of system-scale hydropower planning in Latin America and the Caribbean, and proposes a new framework for sustainable basin-wide hydropower planning that will inform our work not only in the region, but globally.
