value.Name: Center for Sustainable Hydropower
value.BriefDescription: Launch the Center directly with Chinese companies, relevant agencies and other partners to provide services to improve the long- term sustainability of future dams, given China’s global importance as the primary funder and builder of dams around the world
value.LongDescription: Protect critical river ecosystems and services globally through incorporating environmentally sustainable approaches into the practices of the world’s largest developers and governments in the regions with the greatest amount of potential and current hydropower development.The landscape of hydropower has evolved and countries such as China are now the major developers and funders of hydropower. To move the global hydropower sector toward sustainability—and to protect critical river ecosystems and services—the Conservany and other NGOs must build capacity and partnerships in the places where hydropower is being built and where decisions are being made. Through the Center for Sustainable Hydropower, the Conservancy will engage directly with the leaders of the largest developers and funders of hydropower and also with governments in the regions undergoing current or imminent hydropower expansion.

value.Name: Magdalena
value.BriefDescription: Provide scientific tools, promote transparency and collaboration to help Colombia transition to a strategic, basin-scale approach to hydropower development that balances ecological, economic and social considerations with energy needs.
value.LongDescription: Making the CaseColombia faces one of the most critical times in its history. Whilst economic growth has been steadily increasing in the last decade, the country’s social and environmental capital is highly threatened. The Magdalena River, historically the most important waterway of the country and its entire basin, where almost 80% of the Colombian population settles, is under unprecedented pressure. The development of traditional economic activities such as mining, oil extraction, hydropower generation and agriculture with no social and environmental considerations threatens the future and wellbeing of more than 32 million people and the conservation of such a culturally rich and biologically diverse region of the world.The Nature Conservancy is uniquely positioned to address the challenge of bringing together the wide range of stakeholders from the public and private sectors to civil society within the basin and to provide our technical expertise for the sustainable management of the Magdalena River Basin. Over the past six decades, the Conservancy has evolved into a leading voice in freshwater conservation, investing in more than 500 freshwater projects worldwide. Our work encompasses whole ecological systems and involves a wide array of partners such as government agencies, leading water users, managers and energy developers. We are implementing complex strategies across the Mississippi, Colorado, Penobscot, Yangtze, Zambezi and many other river basins, as well as furthering freshwater research and policies at around the world.Plan ContextThis conservation business plan is primarily intended to bring together all the aspects of working in a dynamic, multi-cultural, and economically important watershed under a common vision for the future. It is intended to help the Magdalena team coordinate their work under that vision and articulate TNC’s unique role in integrated management of the basin. As such, the primary audience is TNC’s Magdalena team itself. The document will also serve as the foundation for all future work, and as a basis for determining our role in future opportunities in the watershed. The document will also serve as a foundation for future outreach, marketing and philanthropic materials, and essentially serve as the foundation through which we “tell the story” of our work in the Magdalena.While the primary audience is the Magdalena Team, this document also serves to summarize the Magdalena project within the context of the global challenges and global solutions that frame TNC’s work globally. As such, this plan is targeted to other audiences within TNC (Great Rivers Partnership, the Executive Team, etc.), donors who know us well, and our trustees and Board of Directors.

Accomplishments.AccomplishmentText: The conservation blueprint has been incorporated into the Colombian Ministries as an instrument for planning and licensing in the mitigation hierarchy for infrastructure (e.g. dams, levees, etc.).
A compensation hierarchy has been developed and provided to the Colombia Ministry of Environment for adoption in licensing new infrastructure projects.

The GRP and U.S. Geological Survey host two exchanges—one each on the Mississippi and Yangtze rivers—to help develop aquatic monitoring systems on the Yangtze. As a result, the Chinese government provides $1.9 million to incorporate USGS monitoring protocols into the Yangtze program and explore expansion of the monitoring effort to the Yellow and Amur rivers.

value.Name: Southern Andes Sustainable Food

Less than 1% of this basin is under protection and climate change is fast deteriorating water flow.

value.BriefDescription: Arizona Rivers of the Colorado - Enhance river flows in high priority reaches of the Lower CO, Verde, San Pedro & Bill Williams Rivers. Increase CO River flows in the Delta to connect to, and enhance the Gulf of CA. Anchor project includes San Pedro Rvr, Verde River & Groundwater, & Las Arenitas.

value.Name: Hawaiian Islands Ecosystems
value.BriefDescription: Restore nearshore reef resources by working with government agencies, local communities, and other partners to identify and co-manage key threats in priority sites while establishing a network of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) over 25% of the Main Hawaiian Islands.
value.LongDescription: Restore nearshore reef resources by working with government agencies, local communities, and other partners to identify and co-manage key threats in priority sites while establishing a network of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) over 25% of the Main Hawaiian Islands.

value.Name: Palmyra
value.BriefDescription: TNC bought this spectacular marine wilderness area in 2000. Today, Palmyra is a national marine monument protected by  TNC and the U.S. F & WS. The Palmyra Atoll Research Consortium will be a center for scientific study of global climate change, coral reefs, marine restoration and invasive species.

value.Name: HI Maui Kapunakea
value.BriefDescription: This 1264 acre preserve climbs from dry forest at 1,600' to wet forests and montane bogs at 5,400.  There are 11 different natural communities and 24 rare plant species within it.   It is a watershed that provides water to area residents, farms and businesses,  managed by TNC with the Hawaii DLNR.

value.Name: Kona Hema
value.BriefDescription: TNC's Kona Hema Preserve protects part of an ancient koa forest. Native forests, rare birds and plants are part of Kona's native biodiversity. Logging, grazing, and invasive plants and animals have threatened the biological viability.  TNC works to preserve and research sustainable koa forestry.

value.Name: HI Molokai Pelekunu
value.BriefDescription: In 1986 TNC created this 5759 acre preserve.  It includes the highest sea cliffs in the world, rising 3,000 feet above sea level. We protect the rainforest, sea cliffs and Pelekunu Stream which contains most of Hawaii's aquatic fauna. We also protect the valley from invasive animals and weeds.

value.Name: Snake River
value.BriefDescription: The Upper Snake/South Fork Snake River project is within the Utah/Wyoming Mountains and Columbia River Basin Ecoregions. It includes two portfolio sites and one action site. The project area exhibits one of the most extensive cottonwood riparian forests remaining in the western United States

value.Name: Idaho Hemingway Preserve
value.BriefDescription: Ernest Hemingway’s last home is 25 miles from Silver Creek Preserve where he enjoyed the Creek for its duck hunting in autumn. The house was bequeathed to TNC in 1986 along with 10 acres, including a mile along the Big Wood River.  We are committed to the upkeep and the cataloging of its artifacts.

value.Name: Garden Creek Preserve
value.BriefDescription: Own and manage the Garden Creek Preserve

value.Name: Clearwater Basin (ID)
value.BriefDescription: The Clearwater Basin consists of more than six million acres of mountains, rivers and forests in Idaho which provide essential habitat for elk, salmon, and other fish and wildlife. With the Clearwater Basin Collaborative science and policy initiatives, TNC is helping to ensure healthy forests.

value.Name: Idaho Flat Ranch Preserve
value.BriefDescription: TNC's Flat Ranch Preserve protects grizzlies, moose, pronghorn antelope, migratory birds, aquatic insects, and trout.  Just 15 miles west of Yellowstone, the preserve provides wildflower walks, an interpretive center, spotting scope, fishing, and speakers to help visitors learn about this ecosystem.

value.Name: Idaho Upper Salmon
value.BriefDescription: The springs and streams along the Pahsimeroi and Lemhi Rivers are a benefit for bringing back salmon and steelhead - a 900 mile journey. TNC works with ranchers to restore cold water and stream habitat for fish, and habitat for sage grouse, elk, pronghorn, birds along the Salmon River tributaries.

value.Name: Idaho North Boundary Area
value.BriefDescription: TNC's vision for North Idaho is to protect lands and waters for everything from kokanee salmon to grizzly bears, ducks to moose, as well as sustainable forestry.  At Boundary Creek and McArthur Lake TNC helped protect a total of more than 4500 acres for harvest and for wildlife habitat and movement.

value.Name: Idaho Owyhees/Hells Canyon
value.BriefDescription: Hell's Canyon is the deepest canyon in North America.  TNC began acquiring property here in 1987, more than 13,000 acres, and  transferred nearly 12,000 acres to the BLM. TNC now owns and manages the 1500-acre Garden Creek Preserve for its biological diversity, clean water, wildlife and recreation.

value.Name: Idaho Silver Creek Preserve
value.BriefDescription: The Silver Creek Preserve includes 850 acres plus 10,000 acres in conservation easements. Silver Creek draws tourists for its  trout fishing and birding. Visitors see herds of mule deer, waterfowl, and mayflies hatching.  TNC works to restore habitat, and assists with insect and fish surveys.

value.Name: Boise Ballot for Clean Water and Open Space
Idaho Ball Creek Preserve
value.BriefDescription: A working preserve in Boundary County, Idaho.

value.Name: Utah Bear River
value.BriefDescription: The Bear River provides vital habitat and feeds the Great Salt Lake, a globally vital habitat.  TNC is removing barriers to fish movement and collaborates with Audubon and landowners to implement a management plan, including efforts to control noxious weeds, restore oxbow wetlands and bird habitat.

value.Name: Utah Matheson Wetlands Preserve
value.BriefDescription: The 894 acre Scott M. Matheson Wetlands Preserve is an oasis in the desert, providing habitat to over 200 species of birds, amphibians, and aquatic mammals such as beaver, muskrat and river otter. TNC protects this area for wetland education, and research into habitat usage and population changes.

value.Name: Utah - Colorado River Basin
value.BriefDescription: The Colorado River basin is facing a persistent drought. TNC is working on policy initiatives to develop collaborative, science-based solutions for the river. In 2014, the water of the Colorado River was released in a “pulse flow”  to mimic spring runoff. Scientists already report signs of recovery.

value.Name: Utah Canyonlands Research Center
value.BriefDescription: The Center brings scientists, land managers, ranchers and others to answer questions that define the future of the Colorado Plateau. Researchers aim to provide understanding on how climate change, land use, invasive species, and fire cycles affect ecosystems, to translate into management strategies.

value.Name: Utah Dugout Ranch
value.BriefDescription: The 5200 acre Dugout Ranch is located along the biologically rich Indian and North Cottonwood Creeks. Along with 250,000 acres of grazing allotments, it provides about 255,000 acres of diverse natural areas on the Colorado Plateau. The ranch's large 'relict areas' are of special value to science.

value.Name: Utah Great Salt Lake Shorelands Preserve
value.BriefDescription: The Great Salt Lake Shorelands Preserve is a unique system of salt and fresh water marshes, ponds, pools, sloughs and mudflats. It is a rich feeding ground for tens of thousands of migrating birds, some 250 species, on the Pacific Flyway. TNC's Preserve protects over 4,400 acres of habitat.

value.Name: New Mexico Grasslands
value.BriefDescription: These grasslands in the Chihuahuan Desert provide critical habitat for birds, reptiles and  mammals, including black-footed ferrets, a small herd of bison and the world’s largest black-tailed prairie dog colonies. TNC will use several conservation strategies to protect and restore the grasslands.

value.BriefDescription: New Mexico Rio Grande Water Fund

value.Name: Australia Aridlands
value.BriefDescription: Establish the world’s largest interconnected, intact aridland ecosystem to conserve nature and support Indigenous communities in their efforts to protect and manage their lands.
value.LongDescription:
The Martu Living Deserts Project is a conservation project of global significance with major social, cultural and economic benefits for Martu people. 

Spanning an area twice the size of Alabama, the project assists the Martu people of Australia’s Western Desert to continue their remarkable connection to country by combining modern scientific land management with traditional indigenous cultural practices. 

A partnership between BHP Billiton, Kanyirninpa Jukurrpa and The Nature Conservancy, the project conserves part of the world’s most intact desert.  Through the project, men and women Martu ranger teams work together with scientists to restore traditional burning practices, control feral pests, rehabilitate waterholes and protect threatened species like Great Bilbies and Black-flanked Rock-wallabies.

value.Name: Australia Great Southern Seascapes
value.BriefDescription: Scale up restoration of coastal habitats in bays and estuaries across Southern Australia, including reseeding native oyster reefs.

value.Name: Aust Inactive Mapping Ocean Wealth
value.BriefDescription: This project works to produce -measures of marine ecosystems services associated with coastal habitats and evaluation of their economic and social values

value.Name: Australia Gondwana Link
value.BriefDescription:
Gondwana Link is a collaborative multi-landscape scale project that stretches 1000 km across the lower south-west of Western Australia.
Gondwana Link aims to significantly increase scale of conservation action towards agreed targets and objectives through collaborative planning across 10 landscapes.

value.Name: Australia Northern Australia
value.BriefDescription: Improve fire management, reduce carbon-emitting wildfires and preserve habitat for iconic wildlife across 25 million acres by partnering with Indigenous communities in Northern Australia.

value.Name: Australia Indigenous
value.BriefDescription: Secure 40 mill acres protection by working w/ our Indigenous partners to create Indigenous Protected Areas & remain a model as largest Indigenous protected area system in the world focused on enhancing Indigenous rights to lands, funded with $50 mill in mitigation offsets & corporate investments.

value.Name: Australia Murray-Darling Basin
value.BriefDescription: Demonstrate the use of water markets and impact investment to restore wetlands and cultural heritage lands, support sustainable agriculture and provide financial returns to investors.

value.Name: China
value.BriefDescription: Protect the key biodiversity hotspot in China with the joint efforts of governments and local communities, to ensure the better life of people.
value.LongDescription: Protect the key biodiversity hotspot in China with the joint efforts of governments and local communities, to ensure the better life of people.

value.Name: China Healthy Rivers
value.BriefDescription: Deploy innovative solutions to hydropower development and water source protection that balance environmental outcomes with human needs through partnerships with government agencies and companies in China.

Accomplishments.AccomplishmentText: The Conservancy advised the China Three Gorges Corporation on a water release from the Three Gorges Dam. The corporation closely monitored the release, which is intended to benefit native fish populations, and will use the results to refine the dam’s operations moving forward.
The Conservancy and Changjiang Water Resources Commission sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to work together on sustainable management of the Yangtze River.

The GRP and U.S. Geological Survey host two exchanges—one each on the Mississippi and Yangtze rivers—to help develop aquatic monitoring systems on the Yangtze. As a result, the Chinese government provides $1.9 million to incorporate USGS monitoring protocols into the Yangtze program and explore expansion of the monitoring effort to the Yellow and Amur rivers.

value.LongDescription: CHINA PROTECTED AREAS VISION is to assist the Chinese Government in completing it's program of work under the CBD through refinement of the design and funding of the PA network(Blueprint), pilot projects with MEP and SFA to channel private and other funding resources to PAs and creation of new tools for conservation.

value.BriefDescription: Promote environment friendly agriculture practices, land planning, and international agriculture products trading in China.

value.Name: China Protected Areas
value.BriefDescription: Establish 10 new land trusts that protect pandas and other wildlife while contributing to food and water security; use science to inform smart choices about how private agricultural lands are managed.

value.Name: China: Climate & Energy (inactive)
value.LongDescription: CHINA Climate Change Vision: By 2020 the China climate change program will have contributed to China's approaches to mitigating and adapting to climate change, in which nature-based solutions are widely accepted.

value.Name: China: Climate & Energy
value.BriefDescription: CHINA Climate Change Vision: By 2020 the China climate change program will have contributed to China's approaches to mitigating and adapting to climate change, in which nature-based solutions are widely accepted.

value.Name: China Yangtze River Basin
value.BriefDescription: As China’s energy needs escalate, the government plans to build 12 large dams on the Yangtze to join the Three Gorges Dam. TNC is working with the Chinese government, hydropower companies and other nonprofits to develop sustainable alternatives to these new dams planned for the Yangtze River.

value.Name: China Marine
value.BriefDescription: Scope and establish a new marine program in China that includes making fisheries more sustainable and protecting key marine sites.

value.Name: China Climate Change
value.BriefDescription: Demonstrate forest and freshwater restoration practices that achieve climate, community and biodiversity (CCB) standards; explore other opportunities to increase the Conservancy's impact on climate change in China.

value.Name: China City
value.BriefDescription:
Our goal: fundamentally change the relationship between cities and nature, so that both can thrive. 
Our Solution – Bring Nature and Cities Together

value.Name: China Illegal Products Trade
value.BriefDescription: Reduce demand and sales of illegal goods in China, including timber and ivory, with a special focus on protecting African elephants.

value.Name: Mongolia
value.BriefDescription: Vast temperate grasslands of the Asian steppe are an intact remnant of an imperiled terrestrial habitat type, especially important for the Mongolian gazelle. TNC was invited to help find a balance between good conservation and economic growth and to help guide policies as they are being written.

value.Name: Mongolia Ecosystem Services
value.BriefDescription: Protect 30 percent of Mongolian lands and waters for communities and wildlife, including mapping ecosystems to identify natural areas that provide human benefits.

value.Name: Mongolia Landscape Conservation and Mitigation
value.BriefDescription: Conduct landscape-level planning with multiple partners to protect 30 percent of Mongolia’s most intact grasslands and establish a national mining mitigation system.

value.Name: Mongolia Tosonkhulstai and Effective PA Management
value.BriefDescription: Promote effective management of one million acres of grasslands at the heart of Mongolia's Eastern Steppe through collaborative management, sustainable funding, and building local partners' capacities.

value.Name: Melanesia Community Fisheries
value.BriefDescription: Establish at least three Territorial User Rights to Fishing (TURF) management systems for high-value coastal fisheries in Melanesia that improve livelihoods, increase food security, and protect critical marine ecosystems.

value.Name: PNG Manus CBRM
value.BriefDescription: Community Based Resource Management in Manus, Papua New Guinea

value.Name: Micronesia Challenge
value.LongDescription: With support from The Nature Conservancy, five Pacific Island nations launched the Micronesia Challenge, a commitment to conserve the vast marine and terrestrial resources that sustain these island peoples and cultures. We work with partners from the grassroots to the highest levels to build institutional and financial systems to sustain these collective efforts and ensure they are supported by public policy locally, regionally and globally. This bold conservation initiative, the first of its kind, provides a platform for collaborative, coordinated, cost-effective conservation and has inspired commitments at similar regional levels across the globe. For more information please visit www.micronesiachallenge.org or http://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/regions/asiaandthepacific/micronesia/index.htm

value.Name: Coral Triangle Initiative
value.BriefDescription: The coral reefs spanning Southeast Asia and the Pacific are the richest and most productive on Earth. They underpin large fisheries and tourism industries, a cornerstone of national and local economies, provide livelihoods for hundreds of millions of people in the region.
value.LongDescription:
The coral reefs spanning Southeast Asia and the Pacific are the richest and most productive on Earth. They underpin large fisheries and tourism industries, a cornerstone of national and local economies, provide livelihoods for hundreds of millions of people in the region and food to a billion people in Asia alone. However, indiscriminate coastal development, destructive fishing practices and the impacts of climate change increasingly suffocate, poison and otherwise ravage reefs and mangroves, destroying the resources that the world depends upon. In 2009, the leaders of the six countries located in the Coral Triangle ? Indonesia, Philippines, Malaysia, Timor Leste, Papua New Guinea, and the Solomon Islands came together to launch the Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs, Fisheries and Food Security (CTI-CFF). CTI-CFF is a regional, multi-nation coalition that the Conservancy helped inspire and launch, and provides a platform for regional-level collaborative, coordinated, cost-effective conservation. Through this Initiative, the Conservancy is working with communal landowners, fishermen, and governments to:

1.	To protect the region?s most productive coastlines and reefs through a combination of cutting-edge science, protected area design, policy and legal frameworks.
2.	Ensure sustainable harvests through effective management of coral reefs, fisheries and other natural systems that sustain the lives of people around the world.
3.	Address climate change threats by designing and implementing ecosystem-based adaptation strategies to protect the communities themselves and the natural resources they depend on for shelter and sustenance.
4.	Build a constituency for conservation by identifying and investing in local champions through educational and social marketing campaigns, technical training and support to peer and learning networks and, in turn, creating broad social movements for conservation. 
5.	Pioneer new approaches to conservation. We are sparking change with innovations in climate change adaptation, sustainable finance, and through new groundbreaking partnerships which have the potential to revolutionize  and multiply the impacts of our conservation work across broad geographies.

value.Name: Micronesia Regional Sustainable Finance
value.BriefDescription: Assist government and NGO partners in their efforts to implement the Micronesia Challenge Regional Sustainable Finance Plan and develop ongoing funding of $2 million per year for protected areas networks, fisheries reform, and climate change adaptation across Micronesia.

value.Name: Micronesia Capacity Building hub defunct
value.BriefDescription: Increase local marine-conservation expertise through peer learning networks and hands-on, real-world activities that build skills, such as quickly assessing an ecosystem and its needs and creating effective conservation plans.

value.Name: Asia Pacific Development by Design
value.BriefDescription: Support $100 million in compensatory mitigation funding on mining, energy and infrastructure developments across the Asia Pacific region.

value.Name: Indonesia Coastal Resilience
value.BriefDescription: Increase ecological and human resilience to climate disasters and risks for both coastal urban and rural settings in Indonesia.

value.Name: Micronesia Community Fisheries
value.BriefDescription: Empower fishermen in at least  eight communities in  the Palau's Northern Reefs to implement cost-effective fisheries management approaches, improve enforcement of fishing boundaries, and develop environmentally friendly livelihoods that reduce pressure on fish stocks.

value.Name: Pacific Tuna
value.BriefDescription: Build healthy and sustainable tuna fisheries in the Pacific--the epicenter of the world’s tuna supply--reduce bycatch of vulnerable species associated with tuna fisheries, and improve tuna fisheries’ financial performance and socio-economic returns for communities.

value.Name: Coral Triangle Policy and Financing
value.BriefDescription: Build the political support needed to see all six Coral Triangle countries ratify the initiative in 2014 through our teams in Indonesia and partners like Rare in the Philippines; capitalize on a $350 million challenge fund to leverage over $1 billion for conservation.

value.Name: Lesser Sundas
value.BriefDescription: Savu Sea Marine National Park zoning plan: Get plan ratified by 2017 to deliver critical proof point for Lesser Sunda as a model for how countries can plan their oceanscapes

value.Name: Melanesia Development by Design
value.BriefDescription: Use Development by Design to support positive environmental and social outcomes in the Solomon Islands at three levels: with communities, with the national government, and with the mining industry.
value.LongDescription: In the Solomon Islands, we support government partners, traditional leaders and communities in their efforts to establish locally-managed protected area networks. Our initial investment in one small site led to the establishment of the Pacific's first community managed marine protected area, an undertaking that received global recognition for outstanding efforts to reduce poverty, and prompted a blossoming conservation movement. Tribal chiefs and communities in neighbouring provinces are independently replicating the model as a means of improving their own future prospects and food security. The efforts contribute to the Solomon Islands commitment to the Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs, Fisheries and Food Security and are fully supported by the government

value.Name: Melanesia Ridges to Reef
value.BriefDescription: Extend "ridges to reefs" conservation management across Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands to ensure that natural and cultural resources are managed sustainably and future developments occur in an informed and inclusive manner.

value.Name: PNG RAFT hub defunct

value.Name: Pacific Climate Change Adaptation
value.BriefDescription: Protect 10 vulnerable island sites  in Micronesia and Melanesia (including five atoll systems and five priority watershed catchments) by working with communities and decision-makers to identify climate risks and implement adaptation strategies.

value.Name: Indonesia Bird's Head Seascape Sustainability
value.BriefDescription: Establish long-term funding, including a trust fund, that will ensure effective conservation and management of a network of 12 marine protected areas in the world's epicenter of marine biodiversity.

value.Name: Indonesia Integrated Oceans Management
value.BriefDescription: Develop a marine spatial plan, management recommendations, and governance frameworks to protect coral reefs, fisheries, and migratory corridors across the entire Lesser Sunda ecoregion.

value.Name: Micronesia Protected Area Network
value.BriefDescription: Work with governments and communities in at least three jurisdictions in Micronesia to establish and  effectively manage networks of protected areas that are ecologically representative, conserve biodiversity, address declining fisheries resources, and are resilient to impacts of climate change.

value.Name: Indonesia Riau Ecosystem: Sustainable Landscapes
value.BriefDescription: Collaborate with APRIL corporation to implement best management practices that will benefit people, businesses, and nature and advance Riau Province as a model of Green Growth in Indonesia.

value.LongDescription: Conserve and sustainably use the region’s diverse biological resources and to promote human well-being across the insular Caribbean through effective, ecologically representative, climate resilient and sustainably financed systems of managed and protected areas.

value.BriefDescription: The two primary goals of the Caribbean Challenge are to conserve at least 20% of marine and coastal environments (such as coral reefs and mangroves) by the year 2020 through the establishment of new marine parks; and to establish sustainable finance mechanisms to steward these declared parks.

value.LongDescription:
Our documents can be found on Connect, Upper Mississippi River.  

Look for org chart on Connect too.

Strategic Plan

Situation Analysis
The Mississippi River Basin has emerged as a priority at the global and regional levels of The Nature Conservancy. It has been an historic focus of our North America (NA) Freshwater Team and many basin states have important projects underway as well.  Now that the Global Challenges Global Solutions framework has been adopted and whole systems work is being incorporated into US divisions, the Central Division has assumed responsibility for the Mississippi River system and its associated sub-basins. 
A tradition of independent Chapter approaches has served The Conservancy well when working at spatial scales smaller than most of the recently identified whole system priorities.  However, realizing the full potential of this investment at this scale will require strong internal collaboration, shared leadership and alignment among state chapters as well as other invested operating units throughout The Conservancy (North America Policy and Practice teams, World Wide Office and Global).   

Why Significant: 

The Mississippi River basin is the third largest watershed in the world, draining 41% of the continental U.S.  It is the most biologically diverse temperate river system in the world, hosting globally significant natural diversity – including over 400 species of native freshwater fishes representing half of the diversity in the U.S.  Its rich lands and waters fuel one of the world’s largest bird migrations – a highway connecting life from the arctic to South America. Similarly, the Mississippi River basin serves as an important transportation corridor and a globally significant agricultural landscape for people in the basin and around the world. This economic engine is not boundless, however.  Economic growth has led to significant environmental degradation, affecting not only nature, but also the services it provides.  

The Upper Mississippi is the northern headwaters to the Mississippi. Here, river flows have dramatically changed as a result of:
•	The severing of floodplains from the mainstem and tributaries – resulting in a loss of water holding capacity and subsequently increased water flows and flooding downstream.
•	Direct impacts to river flows by transportation related infrastructure (locks and dams). 
•	Conversion of over 60% of the land has reduced the infiltration of precipitation and subsequently significantly modifying the hydrology of streams and rivers within the watershed.  This in turn is also contributing to water quality deterioration and nutrient loading downstream. 

However, considerable forested watersheds remain intact that provide essential functions and benefits to the Basin’s 72 million residents, notably, the provision of clean and reliable drinking water and predictable river flows.  Yet much of this natural capital is unsecured and under threat from development and new agricultural conversion, and water availability for cities is challenged by poor agricultural practices and the effects of a changing climate.  

Challenges, Drivers and Opportunities

The approaches and underlying concepts that have been applied to the management of the Mississippi River and its tributaries evolved within a somewhat different economic, political and social context.  The intent was to “tame” and “manage” the river and the economic resources to support the effort were available.  Today, there are a number of vested interests in maintaining the status quo.  However, over the last 150 years we have come to a better understanding of the consequences of those management approaches, and are now beginning to realize they have created as many problems as they have purported to solve.  Additionally, the combination of climate change and a significant reduction in the economic resources needed to update and maintain the current infrastructure has created an opening where new “greener” and more economically viable and integrated approaches to river management can be considered.

Poor floodplain management and policies: The challenge is to change floodplain management approaches at a meaningful scale in a profitable agricultural landscape. Demonstrating approaches to address the needs of landowners, flood risk reduction, and environmental health will provide the opportunity to develop markets for floodplain services and improve policy on floodplain management.

Infrastructure: The challenge is to integrate policies in support of alternative designs and operations, and  include more green infrastructure as a viable alternative  to enhance river hydraulics and hydrology, fish and wildlife habitat, and  lower flood risk all while  providing a secure transportation corridor. The opportunity is an aging water resources (Army Corps) infrastructure in urgent need of upgrade. 
 
Cities, agriculture, water quality and the Gulf of Mexico: The challenge includes a growing population that will require clean water for drinking and industrial purposes and the demand on agriculture to produce more products for food and fuel while reducing its impact on the environment. The opportunities include:
•	Regulatory requirements to meet water quality standards and the Hypoxia Task Force goals will bring diverse partners together to meet standards. 
•	Cities, with growing populations and recent water quality and supply concerns, present an opportunity to engage population centers with larger watershed management.
•	Market forces driven by the calls for sustainable products.
•	Farm Bill targeting of funds to Mississippi watershed. 

Theory of Change: 
The Mississippi River Basin has gone through significant habitat alteration, structural development, and management practices that have affected its ability to function naturally and provide services to society. Current agricultural practices, an aging water infrastructure and management approaches cannot adequately address the increasing needs and the risks posed by climate change projections. The remaining natural components of the river basin and those that have been transformed but not eliminated have generally not been considered in the past to be part of the solutions, and have in some cases been seen as the problem.  However, they can contribute significantly to the multiple needs of society and nature with cheaper and longer-lasting results through protection, restoration, and alternative management approaches at appropriate scales.

Recent record-­‐setting floods and droughts, and forecasts for more frequent extreme weather events are stimulating national debates on agricultural and water policy through the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) and Farm Bill, and a consumer-based market to drive changes in corporate supply chain practices.  Ensuring that these policies and practices are improved and implemented to address the needs of a healthy river system and services it provides to society is critical to addressing the issues at appropriate scales.  If policies and practices are adequately structured and implemented, nature would benefit and provide great value to multiple stakeholders and sectors that rely on and are affected by the management of the river basin resources.  


At the UMR whole system scale, we propose to address three thematic areas: 

•	Resilient Floodplains – advancing approaches, policies, finance mechanisms and implementation to broadly protect and restore floodplains to lower flood risk and benefit fish, wildlife and recreation.

•	River Infrastructure – incorporating and considering environmental sustainability in policies and management guidelines to lower long‐term costs and risks to people and nature.

•	Nutrient Reduction/Source Water Protection – testing new finance and policy drivers to support environmental sustainability practices in land management for clean and reliable water.

Scope:
The scope of this plan includes the five states at the northern headwaters of the river -Missouri, Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin.

Overarching Goal:

To contribute to the restoration of ecosystem process in the headwaters of the MS River by collaboratively working across state lines to: 
1) Improve water quality and drinking water security. 
2) Develop new green approaches to transportation infrastructure. 
3) Restore floodplain structure and function.









Floodplain Restoration
Context
From the 1880s through the 1920s, drainage and levee districts were organized along the Upper Mississippi River and its tributaries.  Their main purposes were to drain floodplain areas too wet for agriculture, and to protect such areas, as well as floodplains previously being farmed, from flooding.  Districts constructed levees, isolating floodplains from the river and degrading many natural ecological functions. More recently, the increasing frequency and magnitude of flood events has damaged levees and stressed many of these districts financially.  Several districts have been acquired for conservation purposes in the past.  While fewer opportunities remain the availability of these has not been exhausted.

Outcomes
1.	Protect and restore functional floodplain in natural and working landscapes by 2025. (moving toward an overall goal of approximately 50% of the floodplain with restored and protected functions associate with river – floodplain connection – need to double the current amount of 600,000 acres of protected/functional floodplain to reach the goal). 
2.	Restore and/or protect 50,000 acres by 2017.  
Strategy 1:  Impact Capital for Large Scale Floodplain Acquisition
Assemble large contiguous blocks of floodplain land through an acquisition strategy with private investment capital that can be used in working lands model for floodplains or restored through traditional conservation programs.
Activities 
1.	Conduct a real estate assessment that determines the availability of floodplain lands in the UMR and the average annual turnover in floodplain real estate.  NAFW/States 2015
2.	Landowner contacts will be used to gauge their interest in selling/easements/agreements in target areas within the UMR floodplain. NAFW/States 2016
3.	Using information from 1 and 2 above, determine the likelihood of our success in assembling large blocks of floodplain land that will allow the restoration of floodplain functions through traditional conservation partners and programs or a working lands model (strategy 3). NAFW/States 2016
4.	Pending the decision in 3 above, establish a floodplain holding company and secure investment capital. NA Conservation Projects and Finance  2017
5.	Identify a project site(s) and acquire lands/easements/agreements. NA Conservation Projects and Finance/ NAFW, States 2018.  

Strategy 2: Natural Lands Model for Functional Floodplains
Restore and protect natural functioning floodplains through the support of programs, actions and partnerships that lead to the expansion of natural lands under conservation management.  


Activities
1.	Document and market the Public Private Partnership (PPP) Upper Mississippi River (UMR) Environmental Management Program (EMP) model at Emiquon for other non- profit organizations and for Army Corps to emulate in other programs.  Illinois/North America Fresh Water (NAFW). 2016
2.	Participate in the Habitat Rehabilitation and Enhancement Projects (HREP) prioritization process at the Corps District level to influence the types and locations of projects best suited for restoration of ecological function. States/NAFW Floodplain staff. 2017
3.	Advocate for-
a.	Environmental Management Program (EMP) Full funding for Upper Mississippi River Restoration –that provides both construction funding and project monitoring.  Government relations (GR)/ Worldwide Office (WO)/State Government Relations (GR)/ NAFW Infrastructure staff. Annually.
b.	Navigation and Ecosystem Sustainability Program (NESP) –
i.	Secure funding to keep program off de-authorized project list.
ii.	Secure authorization to begin construction on planned project and appropriation of at least $25 million.  WO/State GR. 2015
c.	Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) directed toward expansion of floodplain protection, e.g., Upper Mississippi River Refuge, Mark Twain Refuge, Middle Mississippi River Refuge, and Shawnee National Forest.  WO/State GR. Annually
4.	Evaluate support needs for other regional programs such as 519 (Illinois River Comprehensive Plan and other national continuing authorities e.g., 206, 1135 and/or state level initiatives. WO and State GR 2015
5.	Aggregate existing floodplain information to design monitoring in demonstration projects that support information needs for advocating changes in policy. TNC Floodplain/Flood-risk management Practice Area- NAFW/ State Gr 2016

**Note-GR activities in this section are also important for the infrastructure strategy
Strategy 3:  Working Lands Model for Functional Floodplains
Develop a working lands model for floodplain management that develops markets for ecosystem services as a funding source and incorporates existing programs (primarily Farm Bill) for floodplain restoration and management.  
Activities 
1.	Identify policy and/or government relations needs that will allow public program support to be integrated into the working lands model.  WO GR/NAFW 2016.
2.	Engage financial experts in ecosystem market development and payment schemes (This is critical and will be emphasized early in this effort). TBD 2016.
3.	Identify a project site(s) with needed lands/easements/agreements that allow site appropriate planning to proceed. NA Conservation Projects and Finance/ NAFW, States 2018.  
4.	Develop a business plan for potential owners/investors based on values for ecosystem services under alternative management scenarios. NA Conservation Projects and Finance, NAFW 2018
5.	Establish monitoring and data needs from project site(s) to demonstrate the economic benefits and viability of this model to floodplain landowners throughout the UMR and other river systems.  NA Conservation Projects and Finance/ NAFW/States  2018
6.	Evaluate data and develop a communications strategy to illustrate economic benefits and viability of working floodplains.  NAFW/States/Marketing  2018

Infrastructure
Context 
The commercial navigation channel of the Upper Mississippi River System is defined as the 866 miles section of the Mississippi River between Minneapolis, Minnesota and the Mississippi confluence with the Ohio River at Cairo, Illinois and the 336 miles of the Illinois River from the Mississippi River to Lake Michigan. The Upper Mississippi River navigation system currently includes 37 locks and dams on both river systems and managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers divided into three districts, St. Paul, Rock Island and St. Louis. 
Beyond the modification to the mainstem of the UMR, an extensive number of large and small dams have been constructed on many of the river’s major tributaries. Central among these is the system of U.S. Army Corps of Engineers dams, operated for multiple purposes such as flood risk management, recreation, fish and wildlife, water supply, and hydropower. 

The Chicago Area Waterway System (CAWS) includes an approximately 130-mile array of natural rivers, canals, locks and other structures in Chicago and northwest Indiana. Constructed beginning in the 1890s, the waterway system diverted polluted water away from the city’s Lake Michigan drinking water source and created a connection across the mid-continental divide to the Mississippi watershed. The CAWS was a 19th century solution to a single problem. Pressure has been building to update this antiquated urban infrastructure from a number of fronts, one of which is as the primary dispersal pathway between the Great Lakes and Mississippi basins for aquatic invasive species. There are several opportunities that are presenting themselves simultaneously that bode well for modernizing the CAWS now, despite solutions that are in the billions of dollars. One is the extreme attention being paid to invasive Asian carp from the Mississippi knocking on the door of the Great Lakes at the CAWS.
Outcomes
1.	Ten Army Corps of Engineers dam operations will have greater flexibility to re-operate the dams for ecological purposes along with traditional use by 2020.
2.	A two-way ecological separation of Lake Michigan and Mississippi basins solution is agreed upon and fully funded by 2017.


Strategy 1: Ecological dam operation will be possible at three Army Corps dams.

Change dam operation at three sites by working with managing agencies and federal policy to provide ecosystem benefits as well as original authorized purpose such as navigation, hydropower, and flood control.   

Activities: 
1.	Complete fourth demonstration drawdown to further understand the value of this restoration tool in the highly degraded conditions of Pool 3.  NAFW 2016 
2.	Work with partners and the Army Corps of Engineers to select the best pool to revise the water control manual to include additional flexibility to make it easier to routinely implement drawdown. 2016 Template plan will serve as a model for revisions to other water control manuals.  NAFW 2017
3.	Determine if Saylorville and Red Rock Dams on the Des Moines River in Iowa can be operated to improve environmental flows and reduce high nutrient loading under the Sustainable River Program (SRP) by 2015.  
4.	Work with Rock Island District to include any potential changes in the updated water control manual. 2016 NAFW/Iowa

Strategy 2: Two way separation of Mississippi River and Great Lakes basin

Advocate with Congress and the Army Corps of Engineers for legislative and administrative measures/funding to put in place infrastructure changes resulting in the two-way, ecological separation of the Great Lakes and Mississippi River Basins.

Activities: 

1.	Work in conjunction with the Great Lakes Project (GLP) to identify and educate members of congressional delegations to support interim legislative/administrative provisions that begin the process of ecological separation. State GR/Marketing 2016
2.	Ensure that UMR Program invasive concerns/priorities/perspectives are integrated into CAWS messaging to Congress and Corps. State GR /Marketing  2015
3.	Provide staff resources to work with strategic Chicago partners and TNC Great Lakes Program to obtain agreements, authorization and funding to restore ecological separation of the Chicago Area Waterway System (CAWS).  Illinois 2017

Source Water Protection/Nutrient Reduction
Context  
Nutrient loading from both agricultural and developed landscapes continues to impact water quality at all scales of the Mississippi River Basin.  In addition, nutrient loading from the Mississippi has a significant impact on the size and intensity of the zone of hypoxia in the Gulf of Mexico.  In order to improve the aquatic habitats within the basin as well as minimize the nutrient load to the Gulf, Mississippi River States have/are establishing quantitative nutrient reduction goals and implementation plans to achieve those goals – in alignment with the EPA Gulf Hypoxia goals. (Agricultural sources contribute approximately 70% and urban sources another 9-12%)  
•	Municipalities and water treatment facilities will be required to meet the nutrient reduction requirements as point sources. They will pursue low cost alternatives including green infrastructure and nutrient trading opportunities. Some corporations have expressed participating in source water protection for the benefit of nature and people. 

•	Greater emphasis will be placed on targeting the implementation of non-point/ag treatment practices to meet states nutrient reduction goals. State and federal funding will be prioritized based on outcomes, targets and collaboration. (Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Funds)
Outcomes
Reverse the trends of gulf hypoxia expansion and inland water quality degradation by restoring the natural processes that reduce, trap and remove nutrient-laden drainage from agricultural watersheds.  Nitrate and phosphorus delivery to the Mississippi River by the five Upper Mississippi states is reduced by 25% by 2034

Strategy 1:  Increase Water security

Partner with cities and corporate sponsors in four UMR states to develop new approaches to increase water security including investing in green infrastructure, increased efficiency of water use, nutrient reduction and/or disaster risk reduction.


Activities

1.	Establish water funds for cities, industry and corporations by engaging with them to define and create the appropriate market mechanisms. Advance projects in Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Illinois.   NAFW/States 2016
2.	Direct protection and restoration activities to portions of watersheds where they serve multiple resource benefit for nature and people. Emphasis is placed on protecting watershed attributes contributing toward watershed health and critical areas where restoration serves multiple long-term benefits. States 2017
a.	Monitor outcomes at each project. NAFW/States 2017
3.	Engage appropriate partners at the front end of each project that will effectively inform the policy framework guiding water infrastructure investments, and water quality and quantity performance standards made by governments first in the UMR, the nation, and relevant private sectors. States/GR/UMR 2015 
4.	Implement conservation practices using existing and new delivery mechanisms at our projects and help direct these funds to other water fund projects. (farm bill, EPA Clean Water Act and state resources) Primary leverage via participation on NRCS State Technical Committee. NAAG/ States 2018

Strategy 2: Precision Conservation
Target and improve farm practices to reduce nutrient loading into receiving streams and waterways in priority watersheds using a private/public partnership. 
Activities 
1.	Engage USDA conservation programs to help states carry out their nutrient reduction plans by directing at least 20% of their water-quality funding to scientifically targeted management practices and riverine process restoration, with payments weighted toward performance. NAFW/States  2016
2.	Work with watershed partners to institutionalize an outcome based targeted approach to implementing conservation practices using Farm Bill, state and private resources. States 2015
3.	Leverage private and public partnerships and the technical and financial resources they provide to secure large funding sources and implement basin scale strategies. NAAG/States/UMR 2017 
4.	Partner with influential corporations to develop and implement new delivery systems that mobilize their customer service network to implement conservation practices. NAAG/States 2016	


Learning
Context
Whole systems are well designed to offer professional growth opportunities and to facilitate information exchange between participating OU’s and between other whole systems. 
Outcome
Staff exchange best practices, problem solve, learn and export successful or new ideas. Staff is motivated and effective and has new professional opportunities.  Trustees are engaged and providing valuable feedback.
Strategy 1-Knowledge Transfer
Activities
1.	Learn what the team needs related to learning and implement.  Develop clear deliverables. UMR 2015
2.	Host one annual meeting designed to exchange ideas, problem solve, stay connected to the whole system and to the whole Mississippi River. UMR 2018
3.	Host at least one site visit each year. UMR/States 2018
4.	Host joint trustee meeting in fall of 2015.  Use topic specific meetings to engage trustees and gain valuable feedback. States/UMR 2015

value.Name: Gulf Of Mexico

value.LongDescription: Gulf of Mexico FY2015

value.Name: GLT Global Agriculture
value.BriefDescription: Drive towards sustainable intensification of agriculture that helps meet demand for food while improving soil, water and habitat conservation in a focal group of countries responsible for over half of supply of corn, soy, sugar cane and beef, and over a third of supply of rice, wheat and potatoes.
value.LongDescription: The sustainable intensification of agriculture helps meet demand for food while recording improvements in soil, water and habitat conservation in agricultural landscapes. TNC will implement that vision in a focal group of countries responsible for over half of global supply of corn, soy, sugar cane and beef, and over a third of global supply of rice, wheat and potatoes. Building out from established centres of strength in the US and Brazil, we will deepen the Conservancy's engagement with agriculture in China, Africa, Indonesia, Colombia, Argentina, Australia and Canada. There is no simple way to define agricultural sustainability, but we will seek to encourage agricultural systems at all scales that are resilient, conserve soils and water, use inputs efficiently and integrate natural habitat into farms and ranches.

value.Name: Climate Smart Agriculture
value.BriefDescription: There is no greater threat to the world food system than climate change. TNC is working with farmers around the world, especially in Africa and the US, to help them adapt to climate stress, mitigate its impacts and still keep producing the food we need.

value.Name: Global Supply Chain Solutions & Partnerships
Countries: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

value.Name: Global Deforestation Commitments
value.BriefDescription: TNC is helping countries and companies eliminate deforestation linked to the production of agricultural commodities, as they make good on zero deforestation pledges around the world. It will help to save the Amazon, and the peat forests of Indonesia, as well as fight climate change.

value.Name: Landscape Level Science and Planning Tools

value.Name: Global Development Risk Assessment
value.BriefDescription: The Global Development Risk Assessment forecasts globally at-risk areas from cumulative development impacts. We plan to launch the tool online,  as an “early warning” decision-support system that will highlight vulnerable people and places in need of greater support and conservation attention.

value.Name: Renewable Energy Initiative
value.BriefDescription: Promote rapid expansion of renewable energy to decarbonize energy systems and avoid catastrophic climate change; ensure renewable energy development occurs without negatively impacting lands and waters critical to people and nature.

value.Name: ARCT DBD
value.LongDescription: Under the Smart Infrastructure and Resource Development global priority, the Nature Conservancy is advancing Development by Design as a strategy to transform mitigation from “band-aid” actions – reactive, site-by-site mitigation of impacts – to a comprehensive approach that considers whole systems, anticipates impacts, and recommends effective actions to keep our natural systems healthy.  Harnessing the Conservancy’s 60 years of landscape and seascape conservation planning experience, we are working with governments, companies, and communities to support smarter development of energy, mining, and infrastructure in the right way and in the right places.

value.Name: Net Positive Impact Alliance

value.LongDescription: The Nature Conservancy’s efforts are focused on implementing large-scale examples of sustainable, low-carbon development that promote economic opportunity, but with substantially lower impact on forest resources. We are drawing from these models to support a broader group of countries in building national low-carbon development programs and to dramatically expand the political commitment, funding, and effectiveness of forest conservation globally. Our areas of geographic focus are Brazil, Indonesia, and Mexico.

value.Name: Transformational Land Protection
value.BriefDescription: Protecting land is where The Nature Conservancy story began. In the US alone, the Conservancy has helped protect ~8 million hectares. To build on this legacy, we will develop projects focused on conserving land at an unprecedented scale in a way that benefits people, nature and the climate.

value.Name: Lands
value.BriefDescription: Balance nature conservation with expanding demand for food, energy and other needed resources in a way that protects the forests and grasslands that sustain our economies, supply our water and clean our air.
value.LongDescription: Healthy forests and grasslands sustain our economies, supply our water and clean our air. But because nature?s value rarely figures in economic decisions, we continue to sacrifice these natural systems as we expand our production of food, energy and other needed resources. The Global Conservation Lands Team will work together with Conservancy programs around the world to address this challenge by advancing four priorities: Smart Infrastructure and Resource Development, Agriculture, Conservation Landscapes, and Indigenous and Communal Conservation.

value.Name: Conservation Landscapes
value.BriefDescription: The Nature Conservancy is committed to the protection of large ecologically significant landscapes that support the needs of both nature and people.  We seek to protect such landscapes as an integrated whole, inclusive of both traditional protected areas and sustainably managed working lands.
value.LongDescription: The Nature Conservancy is committed to the protection of large ecologically significant landscapes that support the needs of both nature and people.  We seek to protect such landscapes as an integrated whole, inclusive of both traditional protected areas and sustainably managed working lands.  By stregthening the enabling conditions that make conservation at this scale successful, and by leading transformative transactions in selected geographies, we will test new approaches and financial models that can be replicated by governments, NGOs and investors to protect similar landscapes around the world.

value.BriefDescription: Adoption of management practices to improve the health and biological potential of the world’s agricultural soils holds the potential to cost effectively sequester carbon while boosting productivity for farmers and ranchers.  TNC is building a comprehensive strategy to lead the way.

value.Name: GLT Natural Climate Solutions
value.BriefDescription: Protect and restore ecosystems through more sustainable land uses that avoid emissions and enhance biological sequestration of carbon. TNC aims to elevate the significance of Natural Climate Solutions through strategic communications, scientific research and policy interventions.

value.Name: Colorado River Basin
value.BriefDescription: We envision a Colorado River Basin whose rivers and streams have healthy flows: enough water, at the right places and at the right times, to sustain healthy river ecosystems and river-dependent livelihoods. We are restoring and permanently protecting flows to the most important CO Basin rivers.
value.LongDescription: We envision a Colorado River Basin whose rivers and streams have healthy flows: enough water, at the right places and at the right times, to sustain healthy river ecosystems and river-dependent livelihoods. Our 10-year goal is to determine how much water is needed to sustain the most important rivers of the Colorado River Basin, develop plans to restore or protect the flows of these rivers, and make significant progress in restoring and permanently protecting flows.

Accomplishments.AccomplishmentText: The Conservancy worked with government and NGO partners to release water from Morales Dam, about 100 miles upstream from the Colorado River’s mouth at Colorado Delta and the Gulf of California. This release helped the Colorado reach its delta for the first time in more than 25 years.

value.Name: Colorado River Delta
value.BriefDescription: Colorado River Delta: Update Minute 319 with Mexico and purchase $10 million in water rights to continue success of recent flows to the Gulf of California and sustain native fishes, birds, and vegetation and provide water for people and recreation.

value.Name: Northwest Territories
value.BriefDescription: Canada’s Northwest Territories is very remote, located north of the 60th parallel. Because mining threatens the integrity of the land, TNC is working with indigenous communities to utilize their knowledge of migration patterns and wildlife distribution, and to help ensure sustainable development.

value.Name: TX Environmental Flows Initiative
value.BriefDescription: Launch a water-transaction market in Texas that benefits bays and estuaries by developing and executing a water transaction in at least one bay system and paving the way for viable transactions in two other systems. Project will assess current water rights within the system, assess the potential via

value.BriefDescription: Track costs/funding specific to Conservation Finance for CA Chapter per Prog Dir EH. -SS 12/17/15

value.Name: CA CARRIZO STEWARDSHIP
value.BriefDescription: The Carrizo Plain stretches along the base of the Temblor Mountains. Its vast grasslands, woodland habitats and vernal pools sustain 15 of California’s  endangered plants and animals. TNC helped grow the protected parcel to its current quarter-million acres. It became a national monument in 2001.

value.Name: California Conservation Track
value.BriefDescription: Creating new Hub Record in order to associate Insight Project P102227 with this Hub Record in order to complete the Insight Project Edit Record form to change the Chapter attribute on the Insight Record, per FRC/Laura B directions, 8/26/15.

value.Name: Childs Meadow Restoration and Carbon Storage Experiment
value.BriefDescription: TNC is restoring Childs Meadow to improve habitat for willow flycatcher and Cascades frog, sequester carbon in riparian vegetation and naturally and human-constructed beaver ponds, and research the restoration impacts. Funding from the Wetlands Restoration for GHG Reduction Program, CA DFW.

value.Name: Mojave Desert
value.BriefDescription: Maintain the Mojave Desert’s viability by siting energy facilities away from natural systems, promoting environmentally-friendly operating protocols and taking conservation measures to mitigate unavoidable impacts.
value.LongDescription: TNC envisions a sustainable Mojave Desert whole system that accommodates responsible renewable energy development for people and Earth’s climate while maintaining the viability of core ecosystems and species. The greatest opportunity for avoiding adverse impacts associated with renewable energy development and driving conservation is incorporation of the mitigation hierarchy into the energy planning, procurement and permitting processes, ensuring that: 1) facilities are sited to avoid impacting natural systems; 2) technology choices and facility operating protocols are made to further minimize impacts; and 3) effective off-site conservation measures are undertaken to mitigate for unavoidable impacts.

value.Name: Nevada Mojave Desert
value.BriefDescription: TNC's work in the Mojave Desert includes protecting the underground Amargosa River, the Eglington Preserve, and the Clark County Wetlands Park for nature education and restoration projects. Because the Mojave is prime for solar energy, TNC is working to make science-based decisions on siting.

value.Name: Nevada Sagebrush Ecosystem
value.BriefDescription: Sagebrush ecosystems once covered much of western North America. They are diminished by many threats, including invasive plants and wildfire, but are critical for the decreasing population of sage-grouse.  TNC  uses Sage-grouse Conservation Forecasting to develop science-based conservation goals.

value.Name: Carson River
value.BriefDescription: The Carson River sustains cutthroat trout. Along its banks are birds, monarch butterflies and mountain lions. TNC combines land protection strategies, restoration projects and community outreach programs with partners working to find conservation solutions that work for people and for nature.

value.Name: Walker Basin
value.BriefDescription: The Walker River feeds a desert terminal lake. Over a century the water level in the lake dropped 150 feet and damaged the river's ability to provide habitat fo plants, animals and people.  Conservation easements on ranches have provided protection on 4400 acres, and helps recharge groundwater.

value.Name: Nevada Independence Lake
value.BriefDescription: The Sierra's Independence Lake is a unique home for rare fish, and its forests are home to black bear, mountain lion, mule deer, eagles and osprey, and mountain beaver.  The TNC works with partners to preserve habitat, reduce the risk of invasives, decrease wildfire, and provide recreation.

value.Name: Smith Creek Ranch Conservation Easement
value.BriefDescription: Acquisition of a conservation easement on 2,785 deeded acres of the Smith Creek Ranch, a working livestock ranch and vital habitat for the greater sage grouse and Lahontan cutthroat trout.  The easement will be a purchase with funds from the NRCS-ALEP and Dept. of Defense.

value.Name: Stillwater – Rose Tract
value.BriefDescription: This project will record costs related to the acquisition of a Conservation asset.  This should be a P-Land component project of the HUB project 822 Nevada Sagebrush Ecosystems.

value.Name: California San Luis Obispo
value.BriefDescription: San Luis Obispo County includes coastline, forests and grasslands, and a diversity of endangered species. To protect these lands TNC works with partners to preserve maritime chaparral, serpentine habitats, grasslands and woodlands and rivers to provide habitat and wildlife migration corridors.

value.Name: California Monterey
value.BriefDescription: Monterey County's natural areas are being converted to vineyards and subdivisions. TNC began this project in 2001 to conserve high-priority sites and ecological linkages. TNC combines land protection with community-based conservation, public policy work, and acquisition of conservation easements.

value.Name: NY Water for Tomorrow
value.BriefDescription: Holistically remodel management of New York’s water resources to sustainably meet ecological, recreational, industrial and drinking water demands, by building  human capacity, accessible information for decision making, and robust engagement of those with the greatest stake in the outcomes

value.Name: NY Urban Conservation CW
value.BriefDescription: We are exploring existing urban conservation efforts to determine how TNC expertise could inform urban conservation work already underway and continuing to partner with Buffalo Niagara Riverkeeper on joint projects.

value.Name: NY NAPA WS CW
value.BriefDescription: CWNY engages with adjacent OUs to strategize how best to conserve the Tug Hill in relation to the larger Northern Appalachian Whole System.

value.Name: NY Connectivity- Rivers and Lakes CW
value.BriefDescription: Play a catalytic role in restoring connectivity and fish passage in the Oswego River, Seneca River, and Finger Lakes system.

value.Name: GLP Native Fisheries NY
value.BriefDescription: To improve the resilience of recreational fisheries we promote and assist in the restoration of native prey fishes to the Great lakes.

value.Name: NY Tug Hill Forest CW
value.BriefDescription: On our 15000 acre Tug Hill Core Forest we are determining and applying appropriate forest restoration techniques to improve resilience.
value.LongDescription: CWNY owns more than 15,000 acres on Tug Hill. This forested, mostly unfragmented area is the southern and westernmost extent of the Northern Appalachian Whole System. We have been working to understand future forest conditions, and in light of climate change have determined that we need to conduct active silvicultural management in order to help increase forest quality and resilience.

value.Name: NY Improve Water Quality CW
value.BriefDescription: TNC works with partners to reconnect floodplains with storm and flood waters to help improve stream health, water quality and lessen the impact of high water on human structures.

value.Name: NY Protection CW
value.BriefDescription: We protect lands and waters that provide habitat and benefits to nature and humans, creating new preserves in which to experience and interpret nature; sometimes our acquisitions become part of larger state and federal land holdings.

value.Name: NY Invasive Species CW
value.BriefDescription: With partners we focus on preventing new invasives from arriving, eradicating those that pose a major threat, and controlling certain invasives in strategic areas that would cause irreparable harm.

value.Name: NY Shoreline Resilience Infrastructure CW
value.BriefDescription: We protect and enhance natural infrastructure that promotes coastal resilience of the Great Lakes, and advocate for, help design, and build the greenest infrastructure when natural infrastructure options are not possible.

value.Name: NY Flagship Preserve CW
value.BriefDescription: At select Preserves that are capable of balancing the needs of people and nature, we are improving access, experimenting with expanded uses (e.g., biking), and using new interpretive approaches and technologies to create a more enjoyable and immersive experience into nature.

value.Name: NY Energy and Infra and Development CW
value.BriefDescription: Using various lines of evidence, including migratory bird habitat, we evaluate the impacts of development projects on nature and people and advocate for the best possible siting and if necessary mitigation of projects.

value.Name: NY Flood Smart Communities CW
value.BriefDescription: Working with local governments we are helping to identify areas vulnerable to flooding and flood damage as well as identifying actions that can reduce flood risk.

value.Name: NY Plan 2014 CW
value.BriefDescription: TNC advocates for the adoption of Plan 2014, a new management plan that will return some of the dynamics of flows to the St. Lawrence River and to the levels of Lake Ontario and restore 64,000 acres of wetlands and increase the resilience of hundreds of miles of shoreline in the U.S. and Canada.

value.Name: NY Stewardship CW
value.BriefDescription: We manage our lands to preserve and improve the condition of the native biodiversity, to meet or exceed our legal obligations, and at select preserves, to enhance the experience of nature for our visitors.
