value.Name: Oregon Forests
value.BriefDescription: Achieve 13 million acres of resilient forests, including 6.5 million acres restored and managed with periodic fire, via collaborative forest forums, demonstrating ecologically based forest restoration, modifying agency policies and programs, and developing innovative restoration funding mechanisms
value.LongDescription: THE CASE FOR ACTIONForests cover nearly 50 percent of Oregon, and nearly half of these forested landscapes are ponderosa pine and dry, mixed-conifer forests that historically persisted under frequent wildfires of varying size, severity and frequency. The ponderosa pine forests at low to mid elevation in eastern and southwest Oregon experienced low severity fires every three to ten years. Mixed conifer forests historically dominated by ponderosa pine, Douglas fir and sugar pine at higher elevations and north facing slopes adapted to a more varied fire regime that included low and high severity fires across the landscape every seven to 25 years. Collectively, fire events both large and small maintained the open structure and species composition of these “frequent-fire” forests in Oregon, and throughout the West.Fourteen million acres of ponderosa pine and dry, mixed-conifer forests span seven National Forests and two Bureau of Land Management districts in Oregon. The ecological condition and health of these forested landscapes affects populations of over 800 forest-dependent species, including imperiled white-headed woodpeckers, northern goshawks, northern spotted owl, and Pacific fisher (pers. comm. Steve Buttrick). The freshwater systems embedded within these forests also support an array of biodiversity, including threatened bull trout, redband trout, Oregon spotted frogs, yellow rails, endemic freshwater mollusks, Chinook and coho salmon, and steelhead.Over the past 100 years, forest management on public lands has altered forest structure and composition, and federal and state fire suppression policies have disrupted the natural fire cycles across the West. Today in Oregon, 9.4 million acres of frequent-fire forests are moderately or highly departed from historic condition. The exclusion of periodic, low-intensity fires, plus the effects of timber harvesting, has altered the structure and composition of forests, creating higher, more uniform stocking densities, increased fuel loads, and a higher proportion of shade-tolerant species.These conditions have heightened the risk and susceptibility of these forests to uncharacteristically large, intense wildfires, in addition to disease, insect outbreaks and drought. As a result, over the past 40 years both the number of fires and the average size of large wildfires on Forest Service lands nationally has increased dramatically (Fig. 1), and concurrently the number of acres burned and associated fire suppression costs have risen sharply (Fig. 2). Going forward, climate change and the anticipated temperature rise and lengthened summers will further increase the likelihood of uncharacteristic wildfires and outbreaks of insects and disease in the future. To address this problem, we must increase the rate of forest restoration on our public lands by 300 percent in the next decade, or face consequences of falling even further behind.While the risk to the health of our frequent fire forests are increasing, Oregon’s forest products infrastructure and a trained work force to implement restoration actions are declining and rural communities are in economic distress. In the past, distrust among key stakeholders was a nearly insurmountable barrier to action. Over the past 10 years, trust has started to re-build and consensus is emerging among diverse stakeholders on how to restore these forested landscapes. Strategies are gaining traction, and leadership from Governor Kitzhaber, our congressional delegation, the state legislature, industry and conservation groups are uniquely aligned. By acting now we can restore the health of our forests and provide timely benefits to people through protection of rural communities, recreation opportunities and municipal drinking water while concurrently increasing delivery of wood products to local mills, helping to abate high unemployment in Oregon’s rural timber dependent Counties.The Conservancy brings knowledge to develop ecologically based treatments, boots on the ground in key landscapes, relationships across diverse stakeholders, and an ecological understanding of the scope and scale of the problem. We take a reasoned approach and commitment to work with, support and lead collaborative efforts, and are recognized by partners and stakeholders as a neutral broker. With colleagues from across the state and country we can translate success on the ground into new state and federal policies, programs and increased funding.Restoring frequent-fire forests is one of seven priority Initiatives in the Oregon Chapter’s 2012-2016 Strategic Plan. The purpose of the Forest Business Plan is to define a long-term vision for success, lay out a five-year action plan and the outcomes we hope to achieve, and identify resources needed to restore Oregon’s forests. This initiative will support and be supported by The Nature Conservancy’s North America Forest Priority and contribute to whole-system conservation in the Upper Deschutes, Klamath and Rogue River basins.

value.Name: Zumwalt Prairie
value.BriefDescription: At 33,000 acres, Zumwalt Prairie is the largest Conservancy acquisition in Oregon. TNC works to remove invasive species, monitor sensitive species such as the sharp-tailed grouse and quaking aspen, and restore riparian areas for fish and birds.  TNC partners with ranchers to manage cattle grazing.

value.Name: inactive - OR Outdoor School
value.BriefDescription: Working on the campaign to secure permanent public funding for Oregon Outdoor School.

value.Name: Crown of the Continent
value.BriefDescription: TNC has purchased more than 510,000 acres of the high peaks, forest, prairie, rivers around Glacier National Park, the Canadian border and Continental Divide. It shelters grizzlies, wolverines, wolves, and Canada lynx. Pressure for recreational development and energy extraction threaten the region.
value.LongDescription: The Crown of the Continent (Crown) is a ten million acre international ecosystem straddling the Rocky Mountains. It is biologically rich and highly intact large landscape that is a critical linkage from Canada to the US along the spine of the Rockies. The long term goal is to prevent fragmentation of critical private lands and maintain landscape connectivity among public and private lands. Leveraging our work with local communities, continued land protection, smart energy strategies, and work to sustain ecosystem health are our best opportunities to sustain the entire Crown system.

value.Name: MT Matador Ranch
value.BriefDescription: TNC's Matador Ranch is 60,000 acres of North America’s best remaining northern mixed-grass prairie. It supports grassland birds, black-tailed prairie dogs and the longest migration of pronghorns on Earth. The ranch is the site of TNC's pioneering grassbank and the hub of research on grassland.

value.Name: MT Northern Great Plains Ops
value.BriefDescription: These glaciated plains support grassland species such as endangered birds, black-tailed prairie dogs, swift fox, and the black-footed ferret.  Threats include cropland conversion, energy development, fencing , and invasive weeds.  TNC uses science and conservation easements to protect the prairies.

value.Name: MT Northern Great Plains Acq Islands Funds
value.BriefDescription: Project to separate funds from a Northern Great Plains acquisition project for specific approved work on the Northern Great Plains of Montana.

value.Name: MT High Divide Stewardship
value.BriefDescription: The vitality of Yellowstone’s wildlife depends on thousands of acres outside the park boundaries. Pressure to develop threatens both wildlife and family ranches. TNC partners with landowners and public land managers for re-vegetation of stream sides, prescribed fire, and revitalizing aspen groves.

value.Name: MT Yellowstone River
value.BriefDescription: Various conservation work on the Yellowstone River in Montana.

value.Name: Milford Neck Conservation Area
value.BriefDescription: Wetland and forest restoration for climate resilience

value.Name: Brandywine Christina Watershed
value.BriefDescription: "The Brandywine-Christina is part of the Delaware River Basin providing drinking water to 60 percent of Delaware’s residents. The watershed is compromised by rural and urban runoff.  Stream habitat surveys, water quality tests, and  clean-up events are being organized with partners.

value.Name: DE Timber Ponders
value.BriefDescription: External bond counsel will send us a favorable opinion timber thinning project; accounting requires separate project record to put the timber sale proceeds in clear record GL that applying those funds to capital improvements. Please feel free at this time to go ahead and proceed.  Robert Gregory

value.Name: Stream Stewards
value.BriefDescription: Engages a diverse audience in a Citizen Science program to monitor stream water quality of the Brandywine Creek. By December 2017, Stream Stewards will lead volunteers to conservation action by generating data that will inform management decisions and restoration efforts in the watershed.

value.Name: Puget Sound
value.BriefDescription: Protect and steward 100,000 acres of floodplains, farms and forests to provide clean water and habitat by leveraging an investment approach with the potential to deliver $100 million per year for restoration.
value.LongDescription: New coalitions are in place to deliver $100 million/year to protect, steward and restore 100,000 acres of floodplains, farms and forests across Puget Sound, so that they deliver the clean water and habitat needed to improve productivity across 10,000 acres of shellfish beds and 100 miles of salmon habitat. The benefits of a coordinated investment approach in Puget Sound are demonstrated through implementation in 4 of 8 priority watersheds of large scale, multiple benefit floodplain restoration projects.

value.Name: Emerald Edge: Olympic Rainforest, Washington State
value.BriefDescription: Emerald Edge: Olympic Rainforest, Washington State

value.Name: Emerald Edge
value.BriefDescription: Improve management across roughly 70 million acres of Emerald Edge forestland and ensure the Great Bear Rainforest’s forest, river and marine ecosystems are sustainably managed and protected from energy infrastructure impacts.
value.LongDescription: Protect, restore and improve forest management to a standard of low ecological risk for at least 70% of the Emerald Edge terrestrial ecosystem (about 70 million acres); we will also ensure management of the Great Bear marine ecosystem according to locally-appropriate Ecosystem Based Management principles.

value.Name: WA Vessel Traffic & Oil Spills
value.BriefDescription: Project for conservation work related to vessel traffic safety and oil spill prevention

value.Name: Ebey's Landing, Washington
value.BriefDescription: This 554 acre site’s ecological treasures include Perego's Lake; the rare and threatened golden paintbrush plant; and rare prairie habitat. TNC scientists are working with researchers from the Univ. of Washington, agencies and partners to restore golden paintbrush and other prairie plant species.

value.Name: Forests for Our Future: Central Cascades
value.BriefDescription: Forests for Our Future: Central Cascades

value.Name: Foulweather Bluff, Washington
value.BriefDescription: With 101 acres of marsh, beach, and woodland Foulweather Bluff Preserve's most vital feature is its near-pristine brackish marsh, habitat for insects, fish, birds and mammals. It includes forests, marsh, and 3,800 feet of beach.  TNC protects once common old-growth forests of red cedar from logging.

value.Name: South Puget Sound Prairies
value.BriefDescription: TNC has worked to conserve the fragile prairie habitats of the South Puget Sound region. In 2011, the Conservancy transferred this program to The Center for Natural Lands Management, but continues to advocate for funding for more prairie lands, home to colorful wildflowers, butterflies, and birds.

value.Name: WA ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
value.BriefDescription: Funding allocated for Nat Cap grant out to Stanford University

value.Name: Conservation Collaboratory
value.BriefDescription: Create an action-learning network of businesses, governments, and NGOs who will advance our collective capacity to create systemic change efforts that benefit people and (e.g., value-chain integration of soy and beef markets in Latin America; water funds network).

value.Name: The People Survey
value.BriefDescription: Design and implement an organization-wide employee engagement survey. Analyze results and develop a plan to address areas of concern both at the organizational and business unit level.

value.Name: Talent Development and Mobility
value.BriefDescription: Investing in leadership through ongoing skills building and training opportunities for Senior Leaders.

value.Name: California San Diego
value.BriefDescription: San Diego County shelters some 200 imperiled plants and animals. TNC has helped expand the 57,000-acre San Diego National Wildlife Refuge, and created preserves at San Ysabel, Canada de San Vicente, and Ramona Grasslands, and participates in cross-border efforts to protect key migration corridors.

value.Name: California Santa Clara River & Coast
value.BriefDescription: The Santa Clara River and its wetlands are an oasis of biodiversity.  There are 26 endangered or threatened species.  TNC and our partners' strategy here is threefold: restore and protect the Santa Clara River and its tributaries, restore the wetlands at Ormond Beach and secure wildlife corridors.

value.Name: California Santa Ana Mountains
value.BriefDescription: An intense concentration of wildlife survives within this densely developed region. Here is large coastal open space, rare woodlands, impressive grasslands, and extensive chaparral. TNC and its partners work to preserve the Santa Rosa Plateau, the 30,000 acre Irvine Ranch and wildlife corridors.

value.Name: California Cosumnes
value.BriefDescription: In one day, observers tracked 58,000 birds at the Cosumnes Preserve including sandhill cranes. Several species of bats have begun a resurgence.  TNC has made land purchases, conservation efforts and  partnered with ranchers to protect 20,000 acres of vernal pool and blue oak habitats.

value.Name: CA Cos Flint/Larkin/Allen/VanSteyn - ERROR
value.BriefDescription:
Need to delete due to Project incorrectly created in HUB and Insight


Manage select properties located in the Cosumnes River Preserve for Swainson's Hawk habitat.

value.Name: California Lassen Foothills
value.BriefDescription: Development threatens this land of rare wildflowers, vernal pools and habitat.  TNC is restoring  miles of spawning habitat in Battle Creek. Vina Plains Preserve has 4,600 acres of vernal pool wetlands and grasslands, and the 37,540-acre Dye Creek Preserve fosters conservation-compatible ranching.

value.Name: California Sacramento River
value.BriefDescription: TNC has planted over a million seedlings of native plants, created the Sacramento River National Wildlife Refuge, protected a corridor of 24,000 acres of land, with a 2015 goal of 30,000 acres, restored 6,000 acres of riparian habitat, and increased the amount of land available for public use.

value.Name: Arkansas Conservation Forestry
value.BriefDescription: The Coastal Plain of S Arkansas is a mosaic of barrens, prairies, savannas and mixed forest types. The degraded forests are home to at least seven federally listed endangered species. TNC purchased more than 6,600 acres, plus 23,000 acres are co-managed.  Our goal is to conserve 60,000 acres.

value.Name: Arkansas Big Woods
value.BriefDescription: The Big Woods, at 550,000 acres, is the largest corridor of bottomland hardwood forest remaining in the Delta. Forest fragmentation threatens animal species. Rivers have been leveed, dredged, straightened, drained and diverted. Widespread changes in forest and water management are needed.

value.Name: Arkansas Blacklands
value.BriefDescription: The blacklands, dominated by native grasses and wildflowers, began when the Gulf of Mexico receded, leaving a deep mantle of rich, black soil.   The prairies are threatened by agriculture and development.  TNC repairs erosion damage, collects native prairie seeds to plant, and removes invasives.

value.Name: Arkansas Sandhills
value.BriefDescription: The deep sands of the best sandhills create a dry, drought-prone habitat of sparse oak trees and grass. Miller County Sandhills harbors several rare plants adapted to the deepest sands. The sandhills are recovering from disturbances including logging and grazing.  Ecological restoration is ongoing.

value.Name: Arkansas Ouachita River
value.BriefDescription: The 2900 acre Ouachita River Nature Preserve is bottomland hardwood forest with embedded cypress-tupelo sloughs on six miles along both sides of the lower Ouachita River. It is habitat for deer, turkey, black bear, mussels and fish. TNC has developed a forestry management plan.

value.Name: Arkansas Kings River
value.BriefDescription: Kings River Preserve spans some seven miles on both sides of the river, which provides drinking water, recreation, and habitat for many species.  Excessive sediment fills in gravel beds and chokes out organisms essential to the food chain.  TNC works for the health and water quality of the river.

value.Name: Arkansas Karst
value.BriefDescription: The Ozark karst ecosystem is a wilderness of caves, springs and aquifers that have formed in the bedrock of the Ozarks. It harbors at least 60 species found nowhere else on Earth. Karst terrain is very susceptible to pollution.  TNC monitors rare species and water quality at over 200 karst sites.

value.Name: AR Columbus Saratoga CA Brunson Inactive
Emerald Edge: Clayoquot Sound/Great Bear, Canada
value.BriefDescription: This is a land of mist-shrouded valleys and glacier-cut fjords, old-growth forests and rich salmon streams. TNC led a successful fundraising campaign in support of historic land use agreements to prohibit logging on 5 million acres; 19 million more are under strict land management guidelines.

Measures.Name: River Conservation Dollars Mobilized
Measures.BroadCourseOfAction: Influence Government Planning for Siting Hydropower

Measures.Name: River Kilometers Conserved
Measures.BroadCourseOfAction: Influence Government Planning for Siting Hydropower

Measures.Name: Hydropower Investments Affected
Measures.BroadCourseOfAction: Influence Government Planning for Siting Hydropower

value.Name: INDONESIA FISHERIES
value.BriefDescription: Work with industry and fishing communities to put mechanisms in place that will result in sustainable and profitable fisheries, healthy fish stocks, and healthy ecosystems.

value.Name: NY Natural Infrastructure/Ecosystem Services NYC
value.BriefDescription: To improve environmental quality and climate resiliency in NYC, TNC will produce research projects that advance the role of nature in addressing coastal resilience and urban heat island, both significant threats to NYC, in collaboration with the Mayor’s Office of Recovery and Resiliency.

value.Name: NY Urban Program NYC
value.BriefDescription: To develop a robust urban program  that advances coastal resilience through natural infrastructure, enhances environmental quality of life, and develops new leadership for urban conservation, TNC will scope and develop new projects including oyster restoration and urban greenprinting, among others.
value.LongDescription: Billion Oysters: The Harbor School in New York City has asked The Nature Conservancy to help its Billion Oyster Project, an ambitious plan to restore oysters in New York Harbor.  The Conservancy proposes to provide a Lead Oyster Restoration Scientist who would provide oversight and technical advice to The Harbor School and its partners on the design, installation, and monitoring of oyster reef restoration.  The scientist, in a post-doctoral fellowship, would lead and conduct experiments to determine what is needed for successful oyster restoration, expand the current restoration work in the Harbor, and establish protocols for monitoring.  This two-year residency would culminate with the publication of a restoration framework to inform the planning, policy and practice for long-term oyster restoration and the overall health of New York Harbor.

value.Name: NY Government Relations NYC
value.BriefDescription: To improve environmental quality and climate resiliency in NYC,  TNC will advance legislation and policy; maintain relationships with elected and agency officials; build alliances with peer organizations; and conduct media strategies to increase public awareness of and support for legislation.

value.Name: NY Urban Heat Island NYC
value.BriefDescription: To improve environmental quality and climate resiliency in NYC, TNC will produce research projects that advance the role of nature in addressing coastal resilience and urban heat island, both significant threats to NYC, in collaboration with the Mayor’s Office of Recovery and Resiliency.

value.Name: NY Healthy Harbor NYC
value.BriefDescription: This new initiative is to build the foundation for our urban marine ecology agenda while conducting science to assess the Billion Oyster Project's restoration projects.

value.Name: NY Greenprint NYC
value.BriefDescription: The project seeks to present the first-ever comprehensive view of NYC’s open space.  In this first phase we will identify all the existing maps and data and build a strong coalition of partners to advance the work.  This phase will be the groundwork for telling a story about nature in New York.

value.Name: NYC Government Relations
value.BriefDescription: To improve environmental quality and climate resiliency in NYC,  TNC will advance legislation and policy; maintain relationships with elected and agency officials; build alliances with peer organizations; and conduct media strategies to increase public awareness of and support for legislation.

value.Name: NY NRCS Staten Island NYC
value.BriefDescription: Serve as interim sponsor for the acquisition of NRCS floodplain easements in an urban area, covering approximately 50 residential properties in Staten Island, New York City.

value.Name: NY LEAF Ambassadors NYC
value.BriefDescription: To inspire the next generation of our conservation leaders, TNC will create youth development opportunities for LEAF alumni to carry out environmental projects in their own communities.

value.Name: Tapajos Governance EDLP_DELETE
value.BriefDescription:
Analize the social and enviromental impacts related to the Ferrogrão implementation proposal.
Analize potential risks and conflicts of the indigenous and local communities as consequence of the Ferrogrão implementation and build a mitigation risk plan.

value.Name: Para Climate for Nature
value.BriefDescription: This is a Climate for Nature initiative for the green growth compact initiative.

value.Name: VA Cen Apps Protecting and Restoring Lands
value.BriefDescription: VA Cen Apps Protecting and Restoring Lands

value.Name: VA Cen Apps Reducing Energy Impacts
value.BriefDescription: VA Cen Apps Reducing Energy Impacts

value.Name: VA MAS VCR Coastal Habitat & Community Resilience
value.BriefDescription: VA MAS VCR Coastal Habitat and Community Resilience

value.Name: NY Ocean Fisheries LI
value.BriefDescription: LIC Marine staff participation in regional planning meetings to ensure Fisheries activity impacts are reduced to better protect essential ocean habitat.

value.Name: NY South Shore Bays Ecosystem Restoration LI
value.BriefDescription: Spawner sanctuaries in Great South Bay are maintained, stocked & monitored, with a focus on eastern bay by new inlet and Bluepoints areas, with the goal of increasing shellfish density/population when enabling conditions are present.

value.Name: NY LI Sound Ecosystem Restoration LI
value.BriefDescription: Working with partners: advance Seagrass Initiative Protection and Restoration Strategy to conserve sensitive submerged habitats; protect LIS natural shorelines; and restore rivers and embayments in priority LIS coastal watersheds.

value.Name: NY Bluepoints Flagship Preserve LI
value.BriefDescription: Use Bluepoints Preserve as a flagship preserve – promoting it as a “natural laboratory” platform for water quality research, habitat restoration and exemplary “land” management practices, optimizing & leveraging stakeholder engagement while minimizing impact to this recovering ecosystem.

value.Name: NY Species and Habitat Condition LI
value.BriefDescription: Participate/engage in research to develop & implement strategies to ensure our preserves are resilient, specifically: LIC coordination with BRI mercury monitoring project and coordination with SHARP survey on TNC preserves

value.Name: NY Connectivity LI
value.BriefDescription: Review/revisit NY NHP connectivity report & identify appropriate site to restore land/freshwater connectivity for future implement restoration project.

value.Name: NY Invasive Species LI
value.BriefDescription: LIC staff will coordinate with NY Invasives staff on strategies, focusing on the implementation & enforcement of existing Invasive Species laws to prevent the introduction of new invasive species on LI.

value.Name: NY Stewardship LI
value.BriefDescription: Meet or exceed the standards and requirements for land management and monitoring as defined by LTA accreditation process and TNC SOP's, including mgmt/monitoring/maintenance of preserves & trails, tools & equip, easement monitoring and endangered species protection.

value.Name: NY Preserve Facilities LI
value.BriefDescription: Facilities/buildings are pro-actively managed to reduce "emergency" repairs, safeguard asset value and extend asset life to greatest degree possible.

value.Name: NY Mill Cove LI
value.BriefDescription: Continue to work with TNC legal staff & pro bono legal counsel to facilitate and complete transfer of Mill Cove Sanctuary and Mill Cove quasi endowment to the local Tide Mill Sanctuary, a 501c3 organization.

value.Name: NY Freshwater LI
value.BriefDescription: Incorporate LI spatial data/analysis into Water Intelligence Platform (WIP) & associated website and identify appropriate areas for reconnecting and restoring freshwater wetlands on LI.

value.Name: NY Deer Management LI
value.BriefDescription: Work with staff across NY to determine the feasibility of single TNC-NY position on deer management & participate in development of the plan; continue to gather scientific data to evaluate/identify effect of poor/unmanaged deer population; share results with local communities

value.Name: NY Energy LI
value.BriefDescription: LIC will investigate & plan for appropriate solar siting on LI, including incentives, env. review and BMPs; map areas of biological and wildlife resources  & identify appropriate "energysheds";  Coordinate with NYS Energy Team to incorporate solar position into energy program

value.Name: NY Protection LI
value.BriefDescription: Work with local & state partners to protect approx. 250 acres of priority parcels; Advance Clearing Limitations as a significant, non-acquisition, land protection strategy; create criteria and mapping for a new "floodplain protection priority areas”.

value.Name: NY Mashomack Flagship Preserve LI
value.BriefDescription: Maintain the ecological integrity & health of the Preserve; Education program exposes public to nature/natural processes and to TNC’s local & global mission; Manor House is a fully functioning & accessible facility for donor cultivation, TNC conferences/mtgs & edu/outreach programs.

value.Name: NY Natural Resource Navigator
value.BriefDescription: To facilitate climate-smart decision making by natural resource managers, TNC will develop, promote, use, and adapt an interactive toolkit that combines comprehensive spatial data in a webmap with step-by-step decision support and resources for implementation, tailored to users’ objectives.

value.Name: NY Ocean Planning & Conservation LI
value.BriefDescription: Participate in Mid Atlantic Regional Planning Body to develop a draft regional plan that is protective of sensitive habitats and species by Dec 2016.

value.Name: NY NAR Integrated Oceans and Coastal Management LI
value.BriefDescription: Long Island Sound and New England states’ MSP processes are connected so that they are compatible with and inform and advance regional and federal MSP processes, to bring lessons to scale

value.Name: NY WQ Wastewater Technology LI
value.BriefDescription: Nitrogen Reduction Pilot to reduce nitrogen pollution footprint at at LIC office/preserve complex to as close to zero as possible by installing and monitoring new wastewater treatment technology.

value.Name: NY Coastal Resilience Tool LI
value.BriefDescription: With stakeholder engagement, TNC will update and expand the TNC Coastal Resilience Tool with a Long Island Coastal Defense app and develop a Water Quality/Coastal Resilience app (WQ app will improve decision making on nitrogen management).

value.Name: NY Peconic Bays Ecosystem Restoration LI
value.BriefDescription: Spawner sanctuaries in Peconics are maintained, stocked & monitored with the goal of increasing shellfish density/population when enabling conditions are present; scallops transplanted to GSB & oysters grown for Chapter events.

value.Name: NY Climate Resilience Community Plan LI
value.BriefDescription: Community Risk Reduction Act (CRRA) implementation and state & local land use regulations promote wise planning and more natural functioning of coastal processes; acquisition of coastal properties to reduce nitrogen pollution in key coastal communities and salt marsh advancement zones are protected

value.Name: NY Natural Coastal Areas NYC LI
value.BriefDescription: Under NYC Dept of Parks grant, analyze NYC tidal marsh conditions & vulnerability to sea level rise, prioritize restoration opportunity & recommended mgmt practices for marsh restor, protection & to enable marsh migration; Evaluate how approach developed for NYC can be applied to the rest of LI.

value.Name: NY Climate Resilience Adaptation LI
value.BriefDescription: TNC works with partners to ensure more natural hydrological connection and function between coastal waters and tidal wetlands w/fewer manmade impediments by facilitating completion of buy-out and restoration of underlying lands and implementing highest priority culvert upgrades.

value.Name: NY Climate Resilience Ecosystem Restoration LI
value.BriefDescription: TNC works regionally with partners to insure coastal habitat restoration projects and techniques are adequately addressing the impacts of sea level rise, nitrogen pollution, sediment starvation, and other stressors to coastal habitats

value.Name: NY Sustaining Wetlands LI
value.BriefDescription: Continue wetlands research, monitoring, mapping & analysis of existing marshes (collaborating with EPA & DOI) to determine ability to keep pace with SLR & climate change and use information to influence agency staff and natural resource decision-makers

value.Name: NY Warhol Visual Arts Program LI
value.BriefDescription: Visual Arts program under the terms of the Preserve donation. The program includes an "Artist in Residence" (lodging at Fite House) & various workshops conducted in partnership with the Warhol Foundation, local schools and art organizations

value.Name: NY Water Quality Nitrogen Reduction LI
value.BriefDescription: Move constituencies, including policy-makers, to enact long-term Island-wide WQ measures by continuing to build "Science Content" materials, continuing Communication/Advocacy efforts & securing  a stable source of public financing
value.LongDescription: Move constituencies, including policy-makers, to enact long-term Island-wide WQ measures by continuing to build "Science Content" materials (including science communications (videos), ground watershed mapping, DO study, socio-economic analysis), continuing Communication/Advocacy efforts (on-going media campaign & engaging in ballot advocacy as necessary)& securing  a stable source of public financing (including but not limited line-item in EPF and additional state, local & federal funding

value.Name: NY Conservation Investor ADK
value.BriefDescription: Identify individuals and private family foundations that would be willing to financially support land conservation projects though long term (10 – year) no interest loans. This would allow the Chapter time to acquire land and work through a disposition that would protect the tract.

value.Name: NY Finch Protection ADK
value.BriefDescription: Complete disposition of the 161,000 acre Finch project: transfer the remaining addition to forest preserve (Boreas - ~20,500 acres); 1,100 acres will sold to towns or private buyers (1/3 complete.)

value.Name: NY Land Conservation AKD
value.BriefDescription: In partnership with the Adirondack Land Trust TNC is protecting Forestland and Freshwater resources through traditional land protection techniques including Conservation easement acquisitions, fee Co-op projects, preserve additions and CBT's.

value.Name: NY Boquet River Nature Preserve ADK
value.BriefDescription: Pilot a flagship preserve in collaboration with Town of Willsboro to serve as a community recreational gateway and educate public on importance of riparian systems and TNC’s work to protect these habitats in the face of climate change

value.Name: NY Internship Program ADK
value.BriefDescription: A 6-month intern focused on planning and implementing the Chapter's pilot Flagship preserve in the Champlain Valley. Each intern has a broad exposure to all aspects of the Chapter's work -- fundraising, threat abatement, conservation science, stewardship, operations, communications and marketing.

value.Name: NY Stewardship ADK
value.BriefDescription: TNC will manage its preserves, and will develop a pilot Flagship preserve. Staff will provide ongoing stewardship of TNC conservation easements and other legal interests, including monitoring, enforcement, reporting, recordkeeping, responding to inquiries, violation investigation and resolution.

value.Name: NY Follensby Fisheries ADK
value.BriefDescription: To assess Follensby lake trout and cisco populations and provide management recommendations for maintaining the characteristics of an old growth lake trout fishery.

value.Name: NY Follensby Genl Mgmt ADK
value.BriefDescription: Protect the Follensby Pond Tract so as to maintain intact cold water fisheries and other conservation objectives and develop a disposition strategy that will address these objectives. Ongoing work includes lease management, structure inventories and maintenance plans and infrastructure management.

value.Name: NY Forest Policy ADK
value.BriefDescription: TNC will evaluate the effects of biomass energy production on northern forest sustainability and wildlife and develop policy recommendations to meet both energy and conservation objectives.

value.Name: NY NAPA WS ADK
value.BriefDescription: Coordination of the Northern Appalachians Whole System team.

value.Name: NY Summit Stewards ADK
value.BriefDescription: Protect fragile Adirondack alpine habitats through hiker education, stewardship and long-term monitoring through a partnership program with the Adirondack Mountain Club and New York Department of Environmental Conservation.

value.Name: NY Terrestrial Connectivity ADK
value.BriefDescription: To enhance climate resiliency, TNC and partners will secure wildlife linkages between contiguous forested regions by: protecting key tracts; informing local land use planning to secure important wildlife movement areas; and working with transportation agencies to reduce impacts of roads

value.Name: NY APIPP Invasive Species ADK
value.BriefDescription: APIPP coordinates invasive species programming throughout the 7+ million acre Adirondack PRISM with the assistance of over 30 cooperating partners. Work includes education, prevention, surveillance, early detection, rapid response, strategic control, monitoring, and research.

value.Name: NY Freshwater Connectivity ADK
value.BriefDescription: Through demonstration projects, development of science and decision-making tools, outreach to key audiences, and partnerships with communities and transportation departments, TNC will promote improvements in road-stream crossings that improve aquatic connectivity and mitigate flood impacts.

value.Name: NY Atlantic Coast WS
value.BriefDescription: Restore ecologically important fisheries by improving management, protecting and restoring critical habitats in the Hudson River Estuary and Delaware River Basin. The services provided by healthy fish populations will improve ecological function and economic well-being of Atlantic Coast fishermen.

value.Name: NY Securing Water ENY
value.BriefDescription: Catchment or community-scale projects in Eastern New York which contribute to the conservation of freshwater resources and sustainable management of water resources for human communities of the Delaware and Hudson River whole system efforts and pilot new approaches for New York State.

value.Name: NY Wind Siting Tool
value.BriefDescription: To promote appropriate siting of energy infrastructure in New York, TNC will use its recently completed wind siting tool internally and with partners to evaluate siting of wind, pipeline and transmission facilities.

value.Name: NY Del River & Bay WS ENY
value.BriefDescription: As part of NY’s contribution to the Delaware Whole system, we will initiate a suite of management and restoration projects which improve the overall health of the ecological system. Projects will focus on flood mitigation, forest restoration, fisheries management and land protection.

value.Name: NY Energy Policy and Impacts
value.BriefDescription: To reduce carbon emissions in New York, TNC will collaborate with partners on policy initiatives to promote renewables, energy efficiency and distributed energy development, primarily in the context of the Public Service Commission “Reforming the Energy Vision” proceeding.

value.Name: Eastern NY Land Conservation
value.BriefDescription: Utilize traditional and innovative protection tools to conserve critical lands and waters within priority conservation areas including the Neversink River, Delaware River Basin and Catskill Mountains. Reduce the number of preserves we own by transferring ones that do not align with our mission.

value.Name: Eastern NY Preserve Management
value.BriefDescription: Manage ENY's land portfolio according to organizational and regional standards. Focus on messaging and infrastructure at Flagship preserves. Engage volunteers to boost capacity for preserve maintenance. Employ management and restoration strategies that sustain and augment conservation targets.

value.Name: NY Sustainable Forest Resources ENY
value.BriefDescription: Focusing on the Hudson Valley, NYC drinking water supply, upper Delaware River watershed and Catskill region, our forest work will include land protection, deer and fire management, forest pest and invasive species actions, and engagement with private landowners to promote a permeable landscape.

value.Name: NY Forest Carbon ENY
value.BriefDescription: Establish a financially self-sustainable or low expense approach to forest conservation by capitalizing on the carbon markets.   Work with forest landowners throughout New York by creating forest management plans which improve forest health and reward landowners with financial benefits.
value.LongDescription: We will establish a financially self-sustainable approach to forest conservation using new sources of money from the carbon markets.   In doing so, we will protect 15K forested acres by the end of 2017, reaching a protection goal of 250K acres by 2030.  In the process, we will work with forest landowners throughout eastern New York by creating sustainable forest management plans for them, thereby improving forest health and helping landowners benefit from the market demand for certified forest products and carbon offsets.  This will be done with no up-front costs to the landowner and low financial exposure for TNC

value.Name: NY Hudson River Restoration ENY
value.BriefDescription: A robust framework for planning and implementation is needed by stakeholders working to manage infrastructure and natural assets. The Hudson River Comprehensive Restoration Plan will provide an inventory of restoration and adaptation projects to improve habitat and community resilience.

value.Name: NY Ecosystem Services
value.BriefDescription: Work with key researchers to demonstrate the value of nature to people and influence public policy decisions by promoting deeper understanding of the economic impacts of our programs and projects and making the case for ongoing investments in nature and  natural infrastructure

value.Name: NY Conservation Dimensions Tool
value.BriefDescription: A spatial, decision-support tool that incorporates climate change and New York’s natural resources to help guide our terrestrial conservation investments ensuring the greatest conservation outcomes for lands, water, and people.

value.Name: FL Gulf of Mexico
value.BriefDescription: The Gulf has lost nearly 50 percent of its wetlands, 60 percent of its seagrass beds, and 85 percent of its oyster reefs due to oil spills and upriver nutrient runoff. Funding from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill helps TNC conserve the lands, waters and  shorelines, protecting the Gulf’s waters.

value.Name: FL Coastal Resilience and Adaptation
value.BriefDescription: Demonstrate, document and model the role that coastal and natural ecosystems play in building resilience in a vibrant, diverse and vulnerable global city. At 2 project sites we have begun demonstrating, with partner CH2M, what Miami-Dade County’s natural capital can do.

value.Name: FL Longleaf Pine
value.BriefDescription: Four of the best longleaf pine forest remnants are in Florida. They host some 300 bird and 2,500 plant species but are threatened by fragmentation and poor management. TNC works with partners to protect, restore and expand the forests. Our goal is to grow the ecosystem to 8 million acres by 2024.

value.Name: FL Critical Lands and Waters Protection
value.BriefDescription: FL Critical Lands and Waters Protection

value.Name: Everglades
value.BriefDescription: The original 11 million acre Everglades has been diminished by land conversion and drainage. TNC has protected more than 360,000 acres and plans to protect 300,000 more acres for water storage functions, and low-intensity agricultural uses to restore a fully functional, reconnected wetland corridor.
value.LongDescription: From the Everglades headwaters through the southern peninsula and out to estuarine and marine waters*; protect, restore, manage and maintain freshwater supplies and productive habitat for viable fish, wildlife and plant populations that contribute to central and south Florida communities’ sustainability, quality of life and adaptation to climate change.

value.Name: Central Florida Lygodium Strategy
value.BriefDescription: The fern grows fronds up to 125 feet long. It spreads easily, grows quickly, suffocates native habitats in trees and wetlands. TNC works with CFLS (C. Florida Lygodium Strategy) to map and assess Lygodium, to identify and control it, and to educate the public.

value.Name: Central Florida Conservation
value.BriefDescription: Group of projects located in central Florida

value.Name: FL GHG Reduction
value.BriefDescription: Develop a program of facility and equipment/vehicle replacement that will reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

value.Name: MNDK Prairie Pothole Carbon
value.BriefDescription: This project will demonstrate the ability of carbon offset markets to generate new revenues to accelerate rangeland conservation and contribute to climate change mitigation.

value.Name: MNDK Minnesota Headwaters Fund-Capital
value.BriefDescription: Conserving lands through protection, management and restoration that are critical to groundwater and surface water health for aquatic life and human well being.

value.Name: MNDK Minnesota Headwaters Fund-Support
value.BriefDescription: Support services incurred as a result of the MNDK Minnesota Headwaters Fund. This project will capture the expenses incurred for this work as well the revenue raised to support this portion of the project.

value.Name: Minnesota Headwaters Fund
value.BriefDescription: Conserving lands through protection, management and restoration that are critical to groundwater and surface water health for aquatic life and human well being.

value.Name: MNDK ND Outdoor Coalition
value.BriefDescription: A well-organized North Dakota Outdoor Coalition made up of community leaders will help build the social and political capital needed to advance the conservation discussion in the state.

value.Name: Conservation in Indigenous Lands - DELETE
value.BriefDescription: Support the 'on the ground work' related to conservation areas for rain forests in South America.

value.Name: North Carolina Longleaf Pine
value.BriefDescription: Longleaf pine once blanketed 90 million acres of coastal plain and sandhills.  Since the pines are fire dependent, they are threatened by fire suppression and development. The Conservancy has planted more than 700,000 longleaf seedlings and burns thousands of acres of longleaf forest each year.

value.Name: WI Mukwonago Meyer Cook
value.BriefDescription: Project to track money to acquire property from the Estate of Geraldine F. Cook. There are two distinct tracts and the Cook heirs may decide to sell one, both or neither. All of the land is within the portion of the Mukwonago Project that is eligible for spending Meyer Estate funds.

value.Name: WI In Lieu Fees Wetlands Projects
value.BriefDescription: The WI in–lieu fee program involves the restoration, establishment, enhancement and/or preservation of aquatic resources through funds paid to the Wisconsin DNR to satisfy compensatory mitigation requirements for permits.

value.Name: Science Collaborations
value.BriefDescription: Through the leadership and reputation of the Science Cabinet, we will partner with leading universities that specialize in areas critical to our conservation success.

value.Name: Science Cabinet
value.BriefDescription: Addressing shared challenges for nature and people requires expertise beyond traditional conservation science fields. We will create a small hub of permanent staff connecting to a world-class external scientific network that can rapidly respond to opportunities for problem solving and innovation.

value.Name: SCI-SNAP Coastal Defenses inactive
value.BriefDescription: Provide evidence on when, where and how investments in coastal natural defenses are cost-effective, develop practical guidance and tools for decision-makers and practitioners to implement solutions and identify policy and financial incentives that lead to reduced risks for people and nature.

value.Name: Evidence Revolution
value.BriefDescription: While we aspire to create conservation solutions that aid both people and nature, the lack of evidence showing us how to do so is an enormous challenge. Through the laboratory of our conservation programs, we drive new research that creates the evidence for the connections between people and nature.

value.Name: Science Impact Project
value.BriefDescription: The Science Impact Project, a professional development program that develops the communications and leadership skills of our scientists.

value.Name: Nature Net Fellows
value.BriefDescription: The NatureNet Fellows post-doctoral program will change conservation science by partnering with leading universities to develop rigorous research programs conducted by early-career scientists that tackle the two challenges of climate change: halting and adapting to the change already underway.

value.Name: Science for Nature and People (SNAP)
value.BriefDescription: SNAP is a collaboration with the University of California, Santa Barbara and the Wildlife Conservation Society that provides a platform to convene the academic and conservation communities around tackling these questions like how can protecting nature help secure food, energy and water for people.

value.Name: SCI-SNAP China/Ivory inactive
value.BriefDescription: Bring together a consortium of influential experts to assess the true economic impacts of the ivory trade in China, and its impacts on human livelihoods in China and Africa, and provide policy recommendations to the Chinese government

value.Name: SCI-SNAP Ecological Drought inactive
value.BriefDescription: Synthesize available information on ecological drought under current and future climates and compile examples of ecosystem-based approaches for managing drought impacts.

value.Name: Science Communications
value.BriefDescription: Our science communications program is developing our scientists into thought leaders and telling the stories of science innovation to a broad audience.
